</TD><TD style="border-right:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=73.333><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>-6%</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the first half of 2009, 70.5% of our revenue was generated in the Europe and Americas regions, where the challenging economic environment pressured levels of activity across the board and revenue declined 9.3% from the first half of 2008. &nbsp;The Asia Pacific and Rest of World regions accounted for a combined 29.5% of revenue in the first half of 2009, and each region had an increase in first-half revenue of 4% over the year-ago period. &nbsp;More specifically, the United States accounted for 28.8% of revenues, down from 30.2% in the same period in 2008 as revenues fell 10%. &nbsp;Weakness was widespread in that market with just a few areas, including applications and W-CDMA, able to post increased revenues in the face of economic headwinds. &nbsp;Europe accounted for 33.8% of revenues in the first half of 2009 (10.1% in France, 19.6% in Other Western Europe and 4.0% in Rest of Europe), down from 34.6% in the same period in 2008 (8.1% in France, 21.
2% in Other Western Europe and 5.4% in Rest of Europe). Within Europe, revenue increased 18% year-over-year in France due in part to gains in W-CDMA, but fell 13% in Other Western Europe and dropped 29% in Rest of Europe. Weakness in Europe was especially pronounced in our enterprise business, offsetting a few pockets of strength, like our IP/MPLS service routers. Revenues in the Asia Pacific market in the first half of 2009 increased 4% from the same period in 2008, and increased their share of total revenue from 18.3% in 2008 to 20.1% in 2009. &nbsp;Within Asia Pacific, our GSM business was particularly weak and our CDMA and W-CDMA businesses particularly strong, reflecting the transition from 2G to 3G wireless in China. &nbsp;Revenues in Other Americas in the first half of 2009 fell 12% from the same period in 2008 and their share of total revenue slipped from 8.4% to 7.9%. &nbsp;Rest of World increased its share of total revenue to 9.4% in the first half of 2009, up from 8.5% in the same period in 2008, 
and had a 4% increase in revenue. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Gross Profit</I>. In the first half of 2009, gross profit decreased to 32.3% of revenue, or &#8364;2,426 million, compared to 35.5% of revenue or &#8364;2,829 million in the first half of 2008. The decrease in gross profit was mainly driven by lower volumes, unfavourable shifts in product and geographic sales mix, as well as the recovery of the U.S. dollar. Gross profit in the first half of 2009 included (i) the negative impact of a net charge of &#8364;61 million for write-downs of inventory and work in progress; and (ii) the negative impact of a net charge of &#8364;17 million of reserves on customer receivables. Gross profit in the first half of 2008 included (i) the positive impact of a &#8364; 36 million gain from currency hedging; (ii) the positive impact of a &#8364; 20 million gain from the sale of real estate; (iii) the negative impact of a net charge of &#8364;149 million for write-downs of inventory and work in progress; and (iv) the negati
ve impact of a net charge of &#8364;19 million of reserves on customer receivables. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We sell a wide variety of products in many geographic markets. Profitability per product can vary based on their maturity, the required intensity of R&amp;D and our competitive position. Likewise, profitability per geographic area can vary based on the local competitive environment, our market share and the procurement policy of operators. During the first half of 2009, revenue contraction was generally more pronounced in products and in geographic areas where our profitability has historically been above average. Similarly, the products or areas where we enjoyed revenue growth during the first half of 2009 tend to generate below average margins today. The shift in the product and geographic mix witnessed in the first half of 2009 therefore negatively impacted our gross profit.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>It is very difficult to anticipate the future evolution of the product and geographic mix given our wide offering, contrasted economic trends per geographic area and the volatility in operator capital expenditure. We are nonetheless taking actions in order to offset a potential unfavorable shift in our product and geographic mix. We estimate that these actions, which include the rationalization of technology platforms, savings on the procurement of components and services, the re-engineering of existing products, the improvement of our manufacturing tool and, finally, a complete overhaul of our supply chain, should generate annual savings of &#8364;250 million. This makes up a third of the cost reduction plan of &#8364;750 million that we have currently undertaken.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We estimate that the increase in the value of the U.S. dollar versus the euro which took place in the first half of 2009 compared to the first half of 2008 had a negative impact on our gross profit as a percentage of revenue. This is due to the fact, we believe, that the weight of the U.S. dollar and of currencies linked to the U.S. dollar is higher as a percentage of the cost of goods sold than it is as a percentage of revenue.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 13</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Administrative and selling expenses.</I> For the first half of 2009, administrative and selling expenses were &#8364;1,537 million or 20.5% of revenues compared to &#8364;1,546 million or 19.4% of revenues in the same period in 2008. Included in administrative and selling expenses are non-cash purchase accounting entries resulting from the Lucent business combination of &#8364;61 million in the first half of 2009 and &#8364;58 million in the first half of 2008. They primarily relate to the amortization of purchased intangible assets of Lucent, such as customer relationships. &nbsp;The 0.6% decline in administrative and selling expenses reflects the net impact of conflicting trends &#150; the progress we have made executing on our programs to reduce operating expenses by de-layering our organization and eliminating sales duplication between product groups and regions, which has been largely offset by the unfavourable currency impact of the recovery of 
the U.S. dollar on our U.S. dollar denominated expenses. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Research and development costs.</I> Research and development costs were &#8364;1,345 million or 17.9% of revenues in the first half of 2009, after the capitalization of &#8364;1 million of development expense, a decline of 4.6% from &#8364;1,410 million or 17.7% of revenues after the capitalization of &#8364;57 million of development expense in the same period in 2008. &nbsp;Included in research and development costs are non-cash purchase accounting entries resulting from the Lucent business combination of &#8364;79 million in the first half of 2009 and &#8364;195 million in the first half of 2008. The decrease in purchase accounting entries reflects a decline in the amortization of purchased intangible assets of Lucent, including acquired technologies and in-process R&amp;D, mainly due to the impairment losses accounted for on these intangible assets in 2008. &nbsp;Additionally, research and development costs in the first half of 2008 included a one-
time gain of &#8364;31 million on the sale of intellectual property which was booked against our research and development expense. The 4.6% decline in research and development costs reflects the progress we have made enhancing R&amp;D efficiency by focusing on four key segments &#150; IP, optics, broadband and applications &#150; while we accelerate the shift of our investment toward next-generation platforms, and the reduced impact from purchase accounting for the Lucent business combination. &nbsp;Those two factors have more than offset the unfavorable impacts of the sharp reduction in R&amp;D capitalization, the inclusion of the one-time gain in 2008 and the unfavourable currency impact of the recovery of the U.S. dollar on our dollar denominated expenses. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments.</I> We recorded a loss from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments of &#8364;(456) million in the first half of 2009 compared to a loss of &#8364;(127) million in the same period of 2008. The larger loss in the first half of 2009 reflects the unfavorable impact of the global recession on volumes and pricing, and lower gross margins, all of which more than offset the favourable impacts of our product cost and fixed cost reduction programs and a decline in the purchase accounting entries booked in the first half of 2009. &nbsp;The purchase accounting entries had a negative, non-cash impact of &#8364;140 million in the first half of 2009 as compared t
o &#8364;256 million in the first half of 2008. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Changes in provisions adversely impacted income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments for the first six months of 2009 by &#8364;121 million, of which &#8364;231 million were additional provisions and &#8364;110 million were reversals. Additional product sales reserves (excluding construction contracts) created during the first half of 2009 were &#8364;182 million, while reversals of product sales reserves were &#8364;54 million during the same period. Of the &#8364;54 million in reversals, &#8364;32 million related to reversals of reserves made in respect of warranties due to the revision of our original estimates for these reserves regarding warranty period and costs. This revision was due mainly to (i) the earlier than expected replacement of products under warranty by our customers with more recent technologies and
 (ii) the product&#146;s actual performance leading to fewer warranty claims than anticipated and for which we had made a reserve. In addition, &#8364;10 million of the &#8364;54 million reversal of product sales reserves was mainly related to reductions in probable penalties due to contract delays or other contractual issues or in estimated amounts based upon statistical and historical evidence. The remaining reversals (&#8364;12 million) were mainly related to new estimates of losses at completion. Changes in provisions adversely impacted income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of intangible assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments by &#8364;107 million in the first half of 2008, of which additional provisions were &#8364;216 million and reversals were &#8364;109 million. Additional product sales reserves created during the first half of 2008 were &#8364;171 million while reversals of product sales reserves w
ere &#8364;79 million.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Restructuring Costs.</I> Restructuring costs were &#8364;201 million for the first half of 2009, representing (i) &#8364;113 million of new restructuring plans and adjustments to previous plans; (ii) a valuation allowance and a write off of assets of &#8364;43 million in the aggregate; and (iii) &#8364;45 million of other monetary costs. New restructuring plans cover costs related to the elimination of jobs and to product rationalization and facilities closing decisions. Restructuring costs were &#8364;387 million in the first half of 2008, representing (i) &#8364;367 million of new restructuring plans or adjustments to previous plans; (ii) an asset impairment loss of &#8364;15 million; and (iii) &#8364;5 million of other monetary costs. Our restructuring reserves of &#8364;457 million at June 30, 2009 covered jobs identified for elimination and notified in the first six months of 2009, as well as jobs eliminated in previous years for which total or p
artial settlement is still due, costs of replacing rationalized products, and other monetary costs linked to decisions to reduce the number of our facilities. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 14</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Impairment of Assets.</I> In the first half of 2009, we had no asset impairment charges booked in this specific line item. In the first half of 2008 we took an impairment of assets charge of &#8364;810 million related to our CDMA business, all of which is related to goodwill. The impairment was due to the fact that in the second quarter of 2008, revenues from our CDMA business declined at a higher pace than the company had estimated. This was due to a large extent to the unexpected, strong reduction in the capital expenditure of a key customer in North America. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Post-retirement benefit plan amendment.</I> In the first half of 2009 we booked an additional &#8364;1 million reserve related to litigation, as disclosed in Note 21e (&#8220;Contingencies &#8211; Lucent&#8217;s employment and benefits related cases&#8221;) to our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements, that concerns a previous Lucent healthcare plan amendment. In the first half of 2008 we booked an &#8364;18 million reserve related to ongoing litigation that concerns a previous Lucent healthcare plan amendment (see Note 21e for more detail). </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from operating activities.</I> Income (loss) from operating activities was a loss of &#8364;(658) million in the first half of 2009, compared to a loss of &#8364;(1,343) million in the same period of 2008. The smaller loss from operating activities in the first half of 2009 is mostly due to the combined impact of the absence of any impairment charge as compared with the &#8364;810 million charge taken in 2008, and lower restructuring charges in the first half of 2009 compared with the same period in 2008. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Finance costs.</I> Finance costs in the first half of 2009 were &#8364;120 million, an increase from &#8364;98 million in the comparable year-ago period. &nbsp;The increase is due to a drop in interest earned, from &#8364;93 million in 2008 to &#8364;38 million in 2009, that was larger than the decline in interest paid, from &#8364;191 million in 2008 to &#8364;158 million in 2009. &nbsp;The 2009 declines in both interest earned and interest paid are largely due to lower levels of cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities and financial debt. The decrease of interest rates between the first half of 2008 and the corresponding period of 2009 explains also the decrease of interest earned between these two periods. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Other financial income (loss).</I> Other financial income was &#8364;142 million in the first half of 2009, compared to &#8364;193 million in the same period in 2008. In the first half of 2009, other financial income consisted primarily of (i) a capital gain of &#8364;255 million related to the disposal of Thales shares, (ii) a gain of &#8364;50 million related to the partial repurchase of Lucent&#8217;s 7.75% bond due March 2017, and (iii) a loss of &#8364;175 million related to a change in the estimated future cash flows related to Lucent&#8217;s 2.875% Series A convertible debenture. In the first half of 2008, other financial income consisted primarily of income of &#8364;204 million which represented the difference between the expected financial return on the assets and the interest cost on the obligations of the pension and post-retirement benefit plans, which fell to &#8364;14 million in 2009. The decrease of the pension credit is mainly due to 
the decrease of the expected rate of return and the fair value of the pension plan assets as explained in note 2-g of our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Share in net income (losses) of equity affiliates.</I> Share in net losses of equity affiliates was &#8364;(6) million during the first half of 2009, compared with income of &#8364;56 million during the same period in 2008. &nbsp;The decline is largely due to the reclassification of our Thales shares from net assets in equity affiliates to assets held for sale as of the announcement on December 19, 2008 of a definitive agreement to sell our stake in Thales to Dassault Aviation. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) before income tax and discontinued operations.</I> Income (loss) before income tax and discontinued operations was a loss of &#8364;(642) million in the first half of 2009 compared to a loss of &#8364;(1,192) million in the same period of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income tax (expense) benefit.</I> We had an income tax benefit of &#8364;93 million for the six months ended June 30, 2009, compared to an income tax expense of &#8364;(69) million for the six months ended June 30, 2008. The income tax benefit for the first half of 2009 resulted from a current income tax charge of &#8364;(11) million offset by a net deferred income tax benefit of &#8364;104 million. The &#8364;104 million net deferred tax benefit includes deferred income tax benefits of &#8364;62 million related to the reversal of deferred tax liabilities accounted for in the purchase price allocation of the Lucent combination and a &#8364;68 million reversal of deferred tax liabilities related to the Lucent 2.875% Series A convertible debenture. The &#8364;(69) million income tax expense for the first six months of 2008 resulted from a current income tax charge of &#8364;(53) million and a net deferred income tax charge of &#8364;(16) million. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from continuing operations.</I> We had a loss from continuing operations of &#8364;(549) million in the first half of 2009 compared to a loss of &#8364;(1,261) million in the same period of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from discontinued operations.</I> There was income from discontinued operations of &#8364;129 million (after external advisors&#8217; fees) in the first half of 2009 due to an adjustment of the purchase price of the Space activities that were sold to Thales in 2007. There was no income (loss) from discontinued operations in the first half of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Minority Interests.</I> A &#8364;(32) million loss was attributable to minority interests in the first half of 2009, compared with income of &#8364;22 million in the first half of 2008. The change from 2008 is due largely to deteriorated operations in China with Alcatel-Lucent Shanghai Bell.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 15</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Net income (loss) attributable to equity holders of the parent.</I> &nbsp;A net loss of &#8364;(388) million was attributable to equity holders of the parent during the first half of 2009, compared with a loss of &#8364;(1,283) million in the first half of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Consolidated Results of Operations for the Six Months Ended June 30, 2008 Compared to the Six Months ended June 30, 2007</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Introduction. </I>On November 30, 2006, Lucent became a wholly owned subsidiary of Alcatel. On December 1, 2006, we and Thales signed a definitive agreement for the acquisition by Thales of our ownership interests in two joint ventures in the space sector, our railway signalling business and our integration and services activities for mission-critical systems not dedicated to operators or suppliers of telecommunications services. In January 2007, the transportation and security activities were contributed to Thales, and in April 2007, the sale of our ownership interests in the two joint ventures in the space sector was completed. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Consequently, the following discussion takes into account our results of operations under IFRS for the six month periods ended June 30, 2008 and June 30, 2007, both of which include six months of results of operations for Lucent and the UMTS radio access business acquired from Nortel on December 31, 2006. Our results for the first six months of 2007 exclude the businesses transferred in January and April 2007 to Thales.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Revenues</I>. Revenues totalled &#8364;7,965 million in the first half of 2008, a decline of 3.0% from &#8364;8,208 million in the first half of 2007. Approximately 52% of our revenues are denominated in or linked to the U.S. dollar. When we translate these sales into euros for accounting purposes, there is an exchange rate impact based on the relative value of the U.S. dollar and the euro. The decrease in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the euro since 2007 had a significant negative impact on our revenues. If there had been a constant euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate in the first half of 2008 as compared to the first half of 2007, our consolidated revenues would have increased by approximately 4.2% instead of the 3.0% decrease actually experienced. This is based on applying (i) to our sales made directly in U.S. dollars or currencies linked to U.S. dollars effected during the first half of 2008, the average exchange rate that applied for the s
ame period in 2007, instead of the average exchange rate that applied for the first half of 2008, and (ii) to our exports (mainly from Europe) effected during the first half of 2008 which are denominated in U.S. dollars and for which we enter into hedging transactions, our average euro / U.S. dollar hedging rate that applied for the same period in 2007. Our management believes that providing our investors with our revenues for the first half of 2008 in constant euro / U.S. dollar exchange rates facilitates the comparison of the evolution of our revenues with that of the industry. The table below sets forth our revenues as reported, the conversion and hedging impact of the euro/U.S. dollar and our revenues at a constant rate:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center>

</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the first half of 2008, the United States accounted for 30.2% of revenues by geographical market, down from 32.6% in the same period in 2007 as revenues fell 10% in that market. &nbsp;The decline in the United States reflected weakness in CDMA and DSL revenues, which was not fully offset by increased sales in W-CDMA, GPON (Gigabit Passive Optical Networking), Enterprise and Services. &nbsp;Europe accounted for 34.7% of revenues in the first half of 2008 (8.1% in France, 21.2% in Other Western Europe and 5.4% in Rest of Europe), up from 32.6% in the same period in 2007 (6.1% in France, 21.3% in Other Western Europe and 5.2% in Rest of Europe). &nbsp;Within Europe, revenue increased 28% year-over-year in France due in part to gains in W-CDMA, while revenue fell 4% in Other Western Europe and increased 1% in Rest of Europe. &nbsp;Revenues in the Asia Pacific market in the first half of 2008 fell 4% from the same period in 2007, but were little changed as
 a percent of total revenue (18.3% in 2008 and 18.4% in 2007). &nbsp;Revenues in Other Americas in the first half of 2008 fell 3% from the same period in 2007 but were unchanged at 8.4% of total revenue. &nbsp;Rest of World increased its share of total revenue to 8.5% in the first half of 2008, up from 8.0% in the same period in 2007, and had a 3% increase in revenue. &nbsp;Regionally, growth in our Enterprise business was solid in Asia Pacific as well as in North America, and gains in our GSM business were driven by network expansions in China, India, the Middle East and Africa. We are also seeing stronger than expected demand for W-CDMA mobile access in emerging markets, especially in Asia.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Gross Profit. &nbsp;</I>Despite the year-over-year decline in revenue in the first half of 2008, gross profit increased to 35.5% of revenue, or &#8364;2,829 million, compared to 30.8% of revenue or &#8364;2,524&nbsp;million in the first half of 2007. The increase in gross profit is due to enhanced pricing discipline, which improves our ability to retain the benefits of our product cost reduction programs, and which reflects our ongoing commercial selectivity as we balance our intent to grow share with our focus on profitable growth. &nbsp;The increase in gross profit is also due to the following: As a result of purchase accounting for the Lucent business combination, Lucent&#146;s inventory was revalued to its fair value and such &#147;step-up&#148; in valuation was reversed once the inventory was sold. The reversal of the inventory step-up related to the Lucent business combination began in 2006 and was largely completed in 2007 (wi
th a negative, non-cash impact of &#8364;258 million in the first half of 2007). Consequently, there was minimal impact in the first half of 2008. Gross profit in the first half of 2008 included (i) the positive impact of a &#8364; 36 million gain from currency hedging; (ii) a &#8364; 20 million gain from the sale of real estate; (iii) the &#8364; 12 million negative impact of compensation expense recognized for share-based payments (stock options); (iv) the negative impact of a net charge of &#8364;149&nbsp;million for write-downs of inventory and work in progress; and (v) the negative impact of a net charge of &#8364;19&nbsp;million of reserves on customer receivables. Gross profit in the first half of 2007 included (i) the negative impact of &#8364;130&nbsp;million related to investments in current products and platforms that we will eventually discontinue, but that we continue to enhance in order to meet our commitment to our customers while preparing to converge them into a common platform; (ii) the pos
itive impact of &#8364;34&nbsp;million from a litigation settlement related to business arrangements with a company in Colombia which was subsequently liquidated; and (iii) the &#8364;11&nbsp;million negative impact of compensation expense recognized for share-based payments. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Administrative and selling expenses</I>. &nbsp;For the first half of 2008, administrative and selling expenses were &#8364; 1,546&nbsp;million or 19.4% of revenues compared to &#8364;1,800&nbsp;million or 21.9% of revenues in the same period in 2007. The 14.1% decline in administration and selling expenses reflects the progress we have made executing on our programs to reduce operating expenses, as well as a favourable currency impact on our U.S. dollar denominated expenses. Also contributing to the decrease in administrative and selling expenses was a decline in purchase accounting entries resulting from the Lucent business combination, from &#8364; 158 million in the first half of 2007 to &#8364; 58 million in the first half of 2008. &nbsp;The purchase accounting entries have a negative, non-cash impact, and they primarily relate to the amortization of purchased intangible assets of Lucent, such as customer relationships. &nbsp;Adm
inistrative and selling expenses also included the compensation expense recognized for share-based payments (stock options) of &#8364; 22&nbsp;million in the first half 2008 as compared to &#8364; 25&nbsp;million in the first half of 2007. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Research and development costs</I>. &nbsp;Research and development costs were &#8364; 1,410&nbsp;million or 17.7% of revenues in the first half of 2008, after the capitalization of &#8364; 57&nbsp;million of development expense, compared to &#8364; 1,512&nbsp;million or 18.4% of revenues after the capitalization of &#8364; 89&nbsp;million of development expense in the same period in 2007. The 6.7% decline in research and development costs is due, as was the case for administrative and selling expenses, to the progress we have made executing on our programs to reduce operating expenses, as well as a favourable currency impact on our U.S. dollar denominated expenses. &nbsp;The reported decline in research and development costs would have been 13.4%, except for an increase in the first half of 2008 in purchase accounting entries resulting from the Lucent business combination, from &#8364; 109 million in the first half of 2007 to &#8364;
 195 million in the first half of 2008. &nbsp;The purchase accounting entries have a negative, non-cash impact, and they primarily relate to the amortization of purchased intangible assets of Lucent, such as acquired technologies and in process research and development. &nbsp;Research and development costs included the compensation expense recognized for share-based payments (stock options) of &#8364; 13&nbsp;million in the first half of 2008 and &#8364; 12&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. &nbsp;Additionally, research and development costs in the first half of 2008 included a one-time gain of &#8364; 31 million on the sale of intellectual property which was booked against our research and development expense.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 17</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>One contributor to our reduced operating expenses (including both administrative and selling expenses and research and development costs) in the first half of 2008, compared with the same period of 2007, has been headcount reductions. &nbsp;Company-wide headcount reductions totalled 2,300 in the first half of 2008 versus 3,800 in the same period of 2007, excluding the impact of managed services contracts.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments.</I> We recorded a loss from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments of &#8364; 127 million in the first half of 2008 compared to a loss of &#8364; 788&nbsp;million in the same period of 2007. This smaller loss reflects improved pricing discipline, the benefits of our product cost and fixed cost reduction programs and a decline in the purchase accounting entries booked in the first half of 2008, all of which more than offset the impact of lower revenues in the first half of 2008. &nbsp;The purchase accounting entries had a negative, non-cash impact of &#8364; 256 million in the first half of 2008 as compared to &#8364; 525&nbsp;mill
ion in the first half of 2007. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Changes in provisions adversely impacted income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments for the first &nbsp;six months of 2008 by &#8364;107 million (of which &#8364;216 were additional provisions and &#8364;109 million were reversals). &nbsp;Additional product sales reserves (excluding construction contracts) created during the first half of 2008 were &#8364;171 million, while reversals of product sales reserves were &#8364;79 million during the same period. &nbsp;Of the &#8364;79 million in reversals, &#8364;29 million related to reversals of reserves made in respect of warranties due to the revision of our original estimates for these reserves regarding warranty period and costs. &nbsp;This revision was due mainly to (i) the earlier than expected replacement of products under warranty by our customer
s with more recent technologies and (ii) the product&#146;s actual performance leading to fewer warranty claims than anticipated and for which we had made a reserve. In addition, &#8364;16 million of the &#8364;79 million reversal of product sales reserves was mainly related to reductions in probable penalties due to contract delays or other contractual issues or in estimated amounts based upon statistical and historical evidence. The remaining reversals (&#8364;34 million) were mainly related to new estimates of losses at completion. Changes in provisions adversely impacted income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of intangible assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments by &#8364;153 million in the first half of 2007, of which additional provisions were &#8364;232 million and reversals were &#8364;79 million. Additional product sales reserves created during the first half of 2007 were &#8364;156 million while rev
ersals of product sales reserves were &#8364;51 million.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Restructuring Costs</I>. &nbsp;Restructuring costs were &#8364;387&nbsp;million for the first half of 2008, representing &#8364;367&nbsp;million of new restructuring plans and adjustments to previous plans, an asset impairment loss of &#8364; 15 million and &#8364;5&nbsp;million of other monetary costs. New restructuring plans cover costs related to the elimination of jobs and to product rationalization and facilities closing decisions. Restructuring costs were &#8364;510&nbsp;million in the first half of 2007, representing &#8364;493&nbsp;million of new restructuring plans or adjustments to previous plans and an asset impairment loss of &#8364;17 million. &nbsp;Our restructuring reserves of &#8364;753 million at June 30, 2008 covered 3,600 positions under restructuring, costs of replacing rationalized products, and other monetary costs linked to decisions to reduce the number of our facilities. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Impairment of Assets</I>. &nbsp;In the first half of 2008 we took an impairment of assets charge of &#8364;810&nbsp;million related to our CDMA business, all of which is related to goodwill. &nbsp;The impairment was due to the fact that in the second quarter of 2008, revenues from our CDMA business declined at a higher pace than the company had estimated. &nbsp;This was due to a large extent to the unexpected, strong reduction in the capital expenditure of a key customer in North America. &nbsp;Although there are new opportunities in other geographic areas, the uncertainty regarding spending in North America has led us to make more cautious mid-term assumptions about the results of this business. &nbsp;In the first half of 2007 we had &#8364;426 million of impairment charges that were booked against our 3G W-CDMA assets, reflecting a delay in revenue generation from our 3G W-CDMA assets as compared to our initial expectations and to 
a reduction in margin estimates. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Post-retirement benefit plan amendment</I>. &nbsp;In the first half of 2008 we booked an &#8364;18 million reserve related to ongoing litigation that concerns a previous Lucent healthcare plan amendment (see Note 21 &#8220;Contingencies &#8211; Lucent&#8217;s employment and benefits related cases,&#8221; for more detail). &nbsp;In the first half of 2007 we booked a &#8364; 265 million credit resulting from certain changes to management retiree healthcare benefit plans. Effective January 1, 2008, prescription drug coverage offered to former Lucent management retirees was changed to a drug plan similar to the Medicare Part D program. This change reduces the benefit obligation projected in the first half of 2007 by &#8364; 265 million, net of a &#8364; 211 million elimination of the previously expected Medicare Part D subsidies.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 18</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from operating activities</I>. &nbsp;Income (loss) from operating activities was a loss of &#8364;1,343 in the first half of 2008, compared to a loss of &#8364;1,459 in the same period of 2007. &nbsp;Contributing to the smaller loss in 2008 were improved pricing discipline, the benefits of our product cost and fixed cost reduction programs, lower restructuring costs and a decline in the purchase accounting entries booked in the first half of 2008 as compared with the same period in 2007. &nbsp;Offsetting some of those positive impacts on the year-over-year change in the loss from operating activities were a larger impairment charge booked in 2008 and the change due to post-retirement benefit plan amendments, from a significant credit in 2007 to a small expense in 2008. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Finance costs.</I> &nbsp;Finance costs in the first half of 2008 were &#8364;98&nbsp;million and included &#8364;191&nbsp;million of interest paid on our gross financial debt, offset by &#8364;93&nbsp;million in interest earned on our cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities. In the first six months of 2007 net finance costs of &#8364;81&nbsp;million resulted from &#8364;209&nbsp;million of interest paid on our gross financial debt, offset by &#8364;128&nbsp;million in interest earned on cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities. The decline in interest paid from the first half of 2007 to the first half of 2008 is due largely to a lower level of gross financial debt, while the decline in interest earned is due largely to a lower level of cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Other financial income (loss)</I>. &nbsp;Other financial income was &#8364;193&nbsp;million in the first half of 2008, compared to financial income of &#8364;231&nbsp;million in the same period in 2007. Other financial income consists largely of the expected financial return on the assets of the pension and post-retirement benefit plans, mainly related to the Lucent pension plan assets. The decline from the first half of 2007 to the first half of 2008 is due largely to a November 2007 re-allocation of the plans&#146; assets which reduced their exposure to equity markets. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Share in net income (losses) of equity affiliates</I>. &nbsp;Share in net income of equity affiliates was &#8364;56&nbsp;million during the first half of 2008, compared with &#8364;65 million during the same period in 2007. &nbsp;While our share of equity affiliates&#8217; earnings included positive contributions from both Thales and Draka in 2007, our share in the first half of 2008 included a contribution from Thales only, since we sold our interest in Draka in the fourth quarter of 2007. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) before income tax, related reduction of goodwill and discontinued operations</I>. &nbsp;Income (loss) before income tax, related reduction of goodwill and discontinued operations was a loss of &#8364;1,192 in the first half of 2008 compared to a loss of &#8364;1,244 in the same period of 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Reduction of goodwill related to deferred tax assets initially unrecognized</I>. &nbsp;In the first half of 2008 there was no reduction of goodwill related to deferred tax assets that were initially unrecognized. &nbsp;In the same period of 2007 there was a &#8364;189 million reduction of goodwill that was due largely to the post-retirement benefit plan amendment &nbsp;described above.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income tax (expense) benefit</I>. &nbsp;We had an income tax expense of &#8364;69 million for the six months ended June 30, 2008, compared to an income tax benefit of &#8364;173 million for the six months ended June 30, 2007. &nbsp;The income tax expense for the first half of 2008 resulted from a current income tax charge of &#8364;53 million and a net deferred income tax charge of &#8364;16 million. The &#8364;16 million net deferred tax charge included deferred income tax benefits of &#8364;112 million (related to the reversal of deferred tax liabilities accounted for in the purchase price allocation of the Lucent combination), that were more than offset by (i) a &#8364;93 million charge from changes in deferred tax mainly due to the reassessment of the recoverability of deferred tax assets in connection with the goodwill impairment test performed in the second quarter of &nbsp;2008; and (ii) a &#8364;35 million deferred tax charge
 related to Lucent&#8217;s post-retirement benefit plans. &nbsp;The &#8364;173 million income tax benefit for the first six months of 2007 resulted from a deferred income tax benefit of &#8364;256 million related to the reversal of deferred tax liabilities accounted for in the purchase price allocation of the Lucent combination which was not fully offset by a current income tax expense of &#8364;40 million and a deferred income tax expense of &#8364;43 million. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from continuing operations</I>. &nbsp;We had a loss from continuing operations of &#8364;1,261 million in the first half of 2008 compared to a loss of &#8364;1,260 million in the same period of 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from discontinued operations</I>. &nbsp;There was no income (loss) from discontinued operations in the first half of 2008, compared with income of &#8364;652 million in the first half of 2007, which consisted primarily of a &#8364;677 million net capital gain after tax on the contribution of our railway signaling business and our integration and services activities to Thales.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Minority Interests</I>. &nbsp;Minority interests were &#8364;22 million in the first half of 2008, compared with &#8364;(14) million in the first half of 2007. &nbsp;The change from 2007 is due largely to our improved operations in China with Alcatel Shanghai Bell.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Net income (loss) attributable to equity holders of the parent</I>. &nbsp;A net loss of &#8364;1,283 million was attributable to equity holders of the parent during the first half of 2008, compared with a loss of &#8364;594 million attributable to equity holders of the parent in the first half of 2007.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR>
<BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 19</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Results of Operations by Business Segment for the Six Months Ended June 30, 2009 Compared to the Six Months ended June 30, 2008</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The following discussion takes into account our results of operations under IFRS for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2009 and June 30, 2008, with results presented according to the new organization structure that became effective January 1, 2009. &nbsp;The new organization includes four groups: Carrier, Applications Software, Enterprise, and Services, while the old organization structure that was in place in 2008 consisted of three business segments &#150; Carrier, Enterprise, and Services. &nbsp;Results of operations for the six months ended June 30, 2008 were originally presented according to the old organization structure but are presented here according to the new organization structure in order to facilitate comparison with the current period. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The table below sets forth certain financial information on a segment basis for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2009 and June 30, 2008. Segment operating income (loss) is the measure of operating segment profit or loss that is used by our Management Committee to perform its chief operating decision making function, assess performance and allocate resources. It consists of segment (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of intangible assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments, excluding the main non-cash impacts of the purchase price allocation (PPA) entries relating to the Lucent business combination. Adding &#147;PPA Adjustments (excluding restructuring costs and impairment of assets)&#148; to segment operating income (loss), as shown in the table below, reconciles segment operating income (loss) with income (loss) from operating activities b
efore restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments, as shown in the table below and the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 20</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>

</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=63.2><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>252</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=98.8><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>21</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=91.133><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>34</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=72.267><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>22</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=60.267><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>10</P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=60.267><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>340</B></P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=694.667 colspan=7><P style="margin:0pt;font-family:Arial" align=left>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=255.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial"><B>Six months ended June 30, 2008</B></P>
