</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=255.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial"><I>PPA Adjustments (excluding restructuring costs &amp; impairment of assets)</I></P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=56.533><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>(256)</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=255.867 rowspan=4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial"><B>Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendment</B></P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF" valign=bottom width=56.533>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF" valign=bottom width=56.533>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF" valign=bottom width=56.533>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=56.533><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>(127)</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=255.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial">Capital expenditures</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=58.133><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>287</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=94.467><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>32</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=80.467><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>37</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=69.333><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>31</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=79.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>12</P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#DFDFDF; border-bottom:1pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=56.533><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>399</B></P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>PPA Adjustments (excluding restructuring costs and impairment of assets).</I> In the first half of 2009, PPA adjustments (excluding restructuring costs and impairment of assets) were &#8364;(140) million, compared with &#8364;(256) million in the first half of 2008. The decline in PPA adjustments in 2009 reflects a decrease in the amortization of purchased intangible assets of Lucent, such as acquired technologies and in-process R&amp;D, mainly due to the impairment losses accounted for on these intangible assets in 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendment.</I> In the first half of 2009, a segment operating loss of &#8364; (316) million for the Group, adjusted for &#8364;(140) million in PPA yields a loss from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendment of &#8364; (456) million, as shown in the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements. In the first half of 2008, segment operating income of &#8364; 129 million for the Group, adjusted for &#8364;(256) million in PPA yields a loss from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendmen
t of &#8364; (127) million, as shown in the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Carrier Segment</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our carrier segment were &#8364;4,603 million in the first half of 2009, a decline of 12.2% from &#8364;5,240 million in the first half of 2008, using current exchange rates. When we translate these sales into euros for accounting purposes, there is an exchange rate impact based on the relative value of the U.S. dollar and the euro. The increase in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the euro in the first half of 2009 vs. the first half of 2008 has tempered the decline in our reported revenues. If there had been a constant euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate in the first half of 2009 as compared to the first half of 2008, our carrier segment revenues would have declined by approximately 17% instead of the 12.2% decrease actually reported.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 21</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our IP division were Euro 572 million, a decrease of 1.4% from the first half of 2008, as accelerating growth in IP/MPLS service routers was more than offset by a material decline in ATM switching revenue. &nbsp;We continue to gain market share in the edge IP routing space, as highlighted by reports published by Dell&#146;Oro, IDC, Infonetics, Ovum and Synergy during the second quarter 2009, and we continue to invest in our IP portfolio to expand our addressable market, announcing &nbsp;the industry&#146;s first 100 Gigabit per second line card for metro, edge and core routing, and the introduction of a new high capacity, router-based solution for the all-IP mobile core network that is a critical element of our end-to-end Verizon LTE roll-out.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our Optics division reflected weakness in the terrestrial segment of the market, where the impact of reduced spending was felt across a widening range of technologies as the first half of the year progressed. &nbsp;Our submarine optics business, however, continued to grow at a strong double-digit rate. &nbsp;Revenues for the Optics division were Euro 1,385 million, a 4.3% decline from Euro 1,447 million in the first half of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>There were contrasting demand trends at play in our Wireless networks division, where revenues of Euro 1,886 million in the first half of 2009 were down 11.9% from the year-ago period. &nbsp;Currency devaluations, economic weakness and the migration to 3G in China had a pronounced impact on carrier spending for legacy technologies in emerging markets, driving a sharp decline in our GSM business. &nbsp;Spending for third generation technologies was much stronger, particularly in China, but a strong double-digit increase in our WCDMA business and some recovery in CDMA activity were not enough to offset the decline in GSM. &nbsp;Finally, the momentum in LTE continues to build: in addition to our selection as one of the two vendors for Verizon, we were selected by several other operators for their LTE trials.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Activity in our Wireline networks division was also materially impacted by the legacy-focused cutbacks in service provider spending for new equipment. &nbsp;Our wireline revenues fell 27.3%, to Euro 817 million in the first half of 2009, driven by pronounced weakness in spending for legacy switching and, to a lesser extent, fixed access technologies.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The carrier segment operating loss was &#8364;(290) million in the first half of 2009 compared with segment operating income of &#8364;81 million, or 1.5% of revenue in the year-ago period. &nbsp;The decrease in segment operating income is due to lower volumes and unfavourable shifts in terms of profitability in both product and geographic sales mix.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Applications Software Segment</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our applications software segment were &#8364;515 million in the first half of 2009 compared to &#8364;477 million in the first half of 2008, an increase of 8.0% at current exchange rates. &nbsp;If there had been a constant euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate in the first half of 2009 as compared to the first half of 2008 our applications software revenues would have decreased by about 1% instead of the 8.0% reported increase.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Carrier applications were a key driver of growth in our applications software segment, particularly in the early part of the first half 2009, with strong gains in spending for rich communications solutions (IMS applications and messaging), subscriber data management, Digital Media &amp; Advertising, and the successful integration of the Motive portfolio. &nbsp;Customer response to the new applications portfolio and to our applications enablement strategy is very encouraging, highlighted by a strong book-to-bill ratio and more than 20 design orders obtained in the first half 2009, mainly in subscriber data management, rich communications and Digital Media &amp; Advertising. &nbsp;From a geographic standpoint, demand remains very strong in North America and strong in Asia Pacific, but more muted in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>There was growth in spending for Genesys, the contact center software activity, in the latter part of the first six months 2009, driven by a surge in demand from the banking sector as well as a major contract with a large Western European operator. &nbsp;This contract highlights the ongoing successful expansion of Genesys from contact centers to customer care, with a particular focus on intelligent workload distribution. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Applications software segment operating loss was &#8364;(51) million in the first half of 2009 compared with segment operating loss of &#8364;(42) million in the year-ago period. &nbsp;Profitability in the segment was lower in &nbsp;the first half of 2009 than in the first half of 2008, reflecting ongoing R&amp;D investments in carrier applications and the fact that ongoing cost reduction initiatives have yet to fully materialize. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 22</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Enterprise Segment</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our enterprise segment were &#8364;503 million in the first half of 2009, a decrease of 16.6% from revenues of &#8364;603 million in the same period of 2008, using current exchange rates. If there had been a constant euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate in the first half of 2009 as compared to the first half of 2008 our enterprise segment revenues would have dropped by 19% instead of the 16.6% decrease actually experienced. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues from Enterprise solutions declined in the first half of 2009 as tough economic conditions and constraints in corporate investment sharply impacted the voice telephony market. &nbsp;&nbsp;Spending for data networking solutions picked up in the latter part of the first half of 2009, offsetting some of the weakness in the voice market. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues from industrial components were the most impacted by global market conditions and declined at a rate well in excess of the 16.6% decline registered by the overall enterprise segment in the first half of 2009, highlighting the highly cyclical nature of the underlying activities.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Demand was weak in all regions but picked up in the Americas later in the period, driven by a large contract in the healthcare market.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Enterprise segment operating loss was &#8364;(42) million in the first half of 2009 compared with segment operating income of &#8364;35 million or 5.8% of revenue in the year-ago period. &nbsp;Most of the segment&#8217;s operating loss occurred early in the first half 2009. &nbsp;Profitability was materially improved in the second quarter, reflecting a more favourable product and regional mix, lower marketing expenses after one-time costs incurred in the first quarter and initial impact of the cost containment actions underway.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Services Segment</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in our services business segment were &#8364;1,670 million in the first half of 2009, an increase of 13.6% over revenues of &#8364;1,470 million in the first half of 2008, using current exchange rates. If there had been a constant euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate in the first half of 2009 as compared to the first half of 2008 our services segment revenues would have increased by 11% instead of the 13.6% increase actually reported. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Managed and Outsourcing solutions grew strongly in the first half of 2009, driven by the implementation of many large contracts signed in 2008. On April 30th, we and Bharti Airtel announced that we have formed a joint venture to manage Airtel&#146;s pan-India broadband and telephone services and help its transition to next-generation networks. &nbsp;Under this JV, we will design, deploy and manage Airtel&#146;s broadband and telephone network across India. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues in the Networks and System Integration (NS&amp;I) division were flat, as a decline in traditional network roll-out services was offset by the demand for more complex network and software integration services.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Maintenance revenues increased in the first half of 2009, with gains in both multi-vendor maintenance and the maintenance of Alcatel-Lucent products. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Services segment operating income was &#8364;23 million or 1.4% of revenue in the first half of 2009 compared with &#8364;66 million or 4.5% of revenue in the year-ago period. &nbsp;Although profitability in the services segment was considerably lower in the first half of 2009 than in the year-ago period, it showed a strong sequential recovery in the second quarter due to much higher margins in maintenance after an abnormally low level in the first quarter, a material improvement in the contribution from NS&amp;I attributable to a better mix of projects completed in the second quarter, and a significant improvement in the profitability of Managed and Outsourcing Solutions.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Liquidity</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Cash and cash equivalents decreased by &#8364; 471 million in the first half 2009 to &#8364; 3,216 million at June 30, 2009. This decrease was mainly due to cash used by operating activities of &#8364; 891 million and to cash used by financing activities of &#8364; 876 million, the latter resulting primarily from the reimbursement or repurchase of financial debt, which was partially offset by cash provided by investing activities of &#8364; 1,177 million (mainly due to the disposal of the shares of Thales that we owned for &#8364; 1,566 million, less expenditures of &#8364; 340 million for tangible and intangible fixed assets).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> &nbsp;
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 23</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Net cash provided (used) by operating activities</I>. Net cash used by operating activities before changes in working capital, interest and taxes was &#8364; 425 million for the first half 2009 compared &nbsp;to &#8364; 41 million of net cash provided for the first half 2008. To calculate net cash used by operating activities before changes in working capital, interest and taxes, the net gain or loss is adjusted for interest income/expense, income taxes and non-cash items (primarily depreciation, amortization, impairments, income statement movements in provisions that have no cash impact and repurchases or changes in financial debt fair values), net gain or loss on disposal of non-current assets, changes in fair values and share-based payments. The net gain or loss is also adjusted for cash outflows in respect of amounts paid during the period that were already provided for at the beginning of the period (mainly ongoing restr
ucturing programs).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The decrease in net cash provided by operating activities before changes in working capital, interest and taxes between the first half 2008 and the first half 2009 is partially explained by the impact in the first half 2009 of &#8364; 621 million of non-cash items (amortization, impairment of assets and items related to financial debt) that were included in the net loss attributable to the owners of the parent at June 30, 2009 of &#8364; 388 million, compared to non-cash items of &#8364; 1,405 million in the first half 2008 that notably included impairment losses of &#8364; 810 million recorded at June 30, 2008 on the CDMA activities. The decrease is also explained by a negative adjustment of &#8364; 372 million for the first half 2009 in respect of financial interest, income taxes, gains on disposal of assets and results of discontinued operations (which included &#8364; 129 million for discontinued operations corresponding to the additional purchase pr
ice to be received by us in the first half 2009 with respect to the disposal in 2007 of our space businesses to Thales, &#8364; 270 million of gains on disposal of assets that included &#8364; 255 million for the disposal of the shares of Thales that we owned and the cancellation of net tax income partially offset by the cancellation of finance costs) compared to a positive adjustment of &#8364; 119 million for the first half 2008 (due mainly to taxes and to finance costs).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net cash used by operating activities was &#8364; 891 million for the first half 2009 compared to net cash used of &#8364; 433 million for the first half 2008. These amounts take into account the net cash used by operating working capital, vendor financing and other current assets and liabilities that amounted to &#8364; 310 million for the first half 2009 and to &#8364; 264 million for the first half 2008. This change is explained by an increase in net cash used of &#8364; 270 million in respect of other non-operating assets and liabilities for the first half 2009 compared to net cash used of &#8364; 95 million for these same elements for the first half 2008, partially offset by a &nbsp;decrease in net cash used by operating working capital. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Net cash provided (used) by investing activities.</I> Investing activities provided net cash of &#8364; 1,177 million in the first half 2009 compared to net cash used of &#8364; 553 million in the first half 2008. The difference is mainly due to the net cash of &#8364; 1,566 million provided from the disposal of our investment in Thales and to a decrease of &#8364; 161 million in purchases of marketable securities (purchases of &#8364; 104 million for the first half 2009 compared to &#8364; 265 million for the first half 2008). On the other hand, purchases of tangible and intangible fixed assets were relatively stable between the first half 2009 and first half 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Net cash provided (used) by financing activities.</I> Net cash used by financing activities amounted to &#8364; 876 million for the first half 2009 compared to net cash used of &#8364; 36 million for the first half 2008. This change was mainly due to repayment of the 4.375% bond maturing February 2009 for an amount of &#8364; 777 million and to a lesser degree to the partial repurchase of the Lucent 7.75% convertible bond for U.S.$ 28 million (approximately &#8364; 21 million).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Disposed of or discontinued operations.</I> Disposed of or discontinued operations provided net cash of &#8364; 118 million for the first half 2009 (actual cash received due to the adjustment in our favour of the purchase price of the space businesses we sold to Thales in 2007) compared to no cash for the first half 2008. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Capital Resources</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Resources and cash flow outlook.</I> Our capital resources may be derived from a variety of sources, including the generation of positive cash flow from on-going operations, the issuance of debt and equity in various forms, and banking facilities, including the revolving credit facility of &#8364;&nbsp;1.4&nbsp;billion maturing in April&nbsp;2012 (with an extension until April&nbsp;5, 2013 for an amount of &#8364;&nbsp;837&nbsp;million) and on which we have not yet drawn (see &#8220;Syndicated facility&#8221; Note 17-d of the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements). Our ability to draw upon these resources at any time is dependent upon a variety of factors, including our customers&#146; ability to make payments on outstanding accounts receivable, lenders&#146; and investors&#146; perception of our credit quality, our ability to meet the financial covenant for our revolving facility and debt and equity market conditions generally
.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Our short-term cash requirements are primarily related to funding our operations, including our restructuring program, capital expenditures and short-term debt repayments. We believe that our cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities, including short-term investments, aggregating &#8364;&nbsp;4,241&nbsp;million as of June&nbsp;30, 2009, are sufficient to fund our cash requirements for the next 12&nbsp;months. Approximately &#8364;&nbsp;622&nbsp;million of our cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities are held in countries, primarily China, which are subject to exchange control restrictions. These restrictions may limit the use of such funds by our subsidiaries outside of the local jurisdiction. Repatriation efforts are underway to reduce that amount. We do not expect that such restrictions will have an impact on our ability to meet our cash obligations.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 24</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In July 2009, we announced new restructuring plans in various European countries that are still being negotiated. These plans could have a material cost impact that, at present, cannot be reliably estimated. This impact will be in addition to cash outlays in respect of previously-announced restructuring plans which we had estimated will be of the same order of magnitude in 2009 as in 2008, that is, approximately &#8364; 570 million.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On the other hand, compared to the &#8364; 901 million spent in 2008, including capitalization of development expenditures, we expect to materially reduce our capital expenditures in 2009, that is, to make capital expenditures in the second half of 2009 of approximately the same amount or slightly more than what we spent in the first half of the year (&#8364;340 million for the first half 2009).We repaid a total of &#8364;&nbsp;777&nbsp;million in respect of our 4.375% bond that matured in February&nbsp;2009. Also in February&nbsp;2009, Alcatel-Lucent repurchased at a substantial discount a part of its 7.75% bond maturing in March 2017 for U.S.&nbsp;$&nbsp;99&nbsp;million. Later in 2009, depending upon market and other conditions, we may continue our bond repurchase program in order to redeem certain of our outstanding bonds.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Based on our current view of our business and capital resources and the overall market environment, we believe we have sufficient resources to fund our operations. If, however, the business environment were to materially worsen, the credit markets were to limit our access to bid and performance bonds, or our customers were to dramatically pull back on their spending plans, our liquidity situation could deteriorate. If we are unable to generate sufficient cash from operations to meet cash requirements in excess of our current expectations, we might be required to obtain the additional cash either through additional operating improvements or from external sources, such as increases in share capital, assets sales or financing from third parties, the availability of which is dependent upon a variety of factors, as noted above.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt;  font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Credit ratings.</I> As of September 3, 2009, our credit ratings were as follows:</P>

<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Moody's</U></I>: on February 18, 2009, Moody&#146;s lowered the Alcatel-Lucent Corporate Family Rating, as well as the rating for senior debt of the Group, from Ba3 to B1. The trust preferred notes of Lucent Technologies Capital Trust were downgraded from B2 to B3. The Not-Prime rating for the short-term debt was confirmed. The negative outlook of the ratings was maintained.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On April&nbsp;3,&nbsp;2008, Moody&#146;s had affirmed the Alcatel-Lucent Corporate Family Rating as well as that of the debt instruments originally issued by historical Alcatel and Lucent. The outlook was changed from stable to negative.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On November&nbsp;7,&nbsp;2007, Moody&#146;s lowered the Alcatel-Lucent Corporate Family Rating, as well as the rating of the senior debt of the Group, from Ba2 to Ba3. The Not-Prime rating was confirmed for the short-term debt. The stable outlook was maintained. The trust preferred notes of Lucent Technologies Capital Trust were downgraded from B1 to B2.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The rating grid of Moody&#146;s ranges from AAA to C, which is the lowest rated class. Our B1 rating is in the B category, which also includes B2 and B3 ratings. Moody&#146;s gives the following definition of its B1 category: &#147;obligations rated B are considered speculative and are subject to high credit risk.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Standard &amp; Poor's</U></I>: on March 3, 2009, Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s lowered to B+ from BB- its long-term corporate credit ratings and senior unsecured ratings on Alcatel-Lucent and on Lucent. The ratings on the trust preferred notes of Lucent Technologies Capital Trust were lowered to CCC+. The B short-term rating on Alcatel-Lucent was affirmed. The B 1 rating on Lucent was withdrawn. The outlook is negative.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 25</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On December 12, 2008, Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s placed on Credit Watch with negative implications the long-term corporate credit ratings of Alcatel-Lucent and Lucent, as well as all issue ratings on both companies. At the same time, the long-term credit ratings were affirmed.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On July&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2008, Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s revised to negative from stable its outlook on Alcatel-Lucent and Lucent long-term corporate credit ratings. At the same time the long and short-term debt ratings of Alcatel-Lucent and of Lucent were affirmed.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On March 19, 2008, the Lucent senior unsecured debt that had not been raised to BB- in June 2007 was so raised. The trust preferred notes of Lucent Technologies Capital Trust were rated B-. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On September 13, 2007, Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s reset the outlook of the long-term corporate credit rating of Alcatel-Lucent and of Lucent. Both outlooks were revised from Positive to Stable. At the same time, Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s BB- long term corporate rating, which had been set on December 5, 2006, was affirmed. The Alcatel-Lucent B short-term corporate credit rating and the Lucent B-1 short-term credit rating, both of which had been affirmed on December 5, 2006, were also confirmed.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The rating grid of Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s ranges from AAA (the strongest rating) to D (the weakest rating). Our B+ rating is in the B category, which also includes B+ and B- ratings. Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s gives the following definition to the B category: &#147;An obligation rated &#147;B&#148; is more vulnerable to non-payment than obligations rated &#147;BB&#148; but the obligor currently has the capacity to meet its financial commitment on the obligation. Adverse business, financial or economic condition likely will impair the obligator&#146;s capacity or willingness to meet its financial commitment on the obligation.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We can provide no assurances that our credit ratings will not be lowered in the future by Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s, Moody&#146;s or similar rating agencies. In addition, a security rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities, and each rating should be evaluated separately of any other rating. Our current short-term and long-term credit ratings as well as any possible future lowering of our ratings may result in higher financing costs and in reduced or no access to the capital markets. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Alcatel-Lucent&#8217;s short-term debt rating allows a limited access to the French commercial paper market for short periods of time.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Total Financial debt</I>. At June 30, 2009, our total financial debt, gross was &#8364;4,286 million compared to &#8364;5,095 million at December 31, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Short-term Debt.</I> &nbsp;At June 30, 2009, we had &#8364;698 million of short-term financial debt outstanding, which included &#8364;532 million related to the principal amount of our Lucent 2.875 % Series A bonds that mature in June 2023 with a put option exercisable as of June 15, 2010, with the remainder representing bank loans and lines of credit and other financial debt and accrued interest payable.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Long-term Debt.</I> &nbsp;At June 30, 2009 we had &#8364;3,588 million of long-term financial debt outstanding.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Rating Clauses Affecting our Debt.</I> Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s and Lucent&#146;s outstanding bonds do not contain clauses that could trigger an accelerated repayment in the event of a lowering of their respective credit ratings.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Syndicated Facility.</I> &nbsp;On April 5, 2007, Alcatel-Lucent obtained a &#8364;&nbsp;1.4 billion multi-currency syndicated five-year revolving bank credit facility (with two one-year extension options). This facility replaced the undrawn &#8364;&nbsp;1 billion syndicated facility, which was to mature in June 2009. On March 21, 2008, &#8364;&nbsp;837 million of availability under the facility was extended until April 5, 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The availability of this syndicated credit facility of &#8364;1.4 billion is not dependent upon Alcatel-Lucent&#8217;s credit ratings. Alcatel-Lucent&#8217;s ability to draw on this facility is conditioned upon its compliance with a financial covenant linked to the capacity of Alcatel-Lucent to generate sufficient cash to repay its net debt. Since the &#8364;&nbsp;1.4&nbsp;billion facility was established, we have complied every quarter with the financial covenant that is included in the facility. The new facility was undrawn at the date of approval by Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s Board of Directors of the financial statements for the six months ended June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Contractual obligations and off-balance sheet contingent commitments</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Contractual obligations.</I> &nbsp;We have certain contractual obligations that extend beyond 2009. Among these obligations we have long-term debt and interest thereon, capital leases, operating leases, commitments to purchase fixed assets and other unconditional purchase obligations. Our total contractual cash obligations at June 30, 2009 for these items are presented below based upon the minimum payments we will have to make in the future under such contracts and firm commitments. Amounts related to financial debt, capital lease obligations and the equity component of our convertible bonds are fully reflected in our unaudited condensed interim consolidated balance sheet included in this document.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 26</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>

<P style="margin-top:2.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(1) To compute finance costs on financial debt, all put dates have been considered as redemption dates. For debentures with calls but no puts, call dates have not been considered as redemption dates. Further details on put and call dates are given in Note 15 of the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements. If all outstanding debentures were not redeemed at their respective put dates, we would incur an additional finance cost of approximately &#8364;&nbsp;408 million until redemption at their respective contractual maturities (of which &#8364;&nbsp;24 million in 2010-2011 and the remaining part in 2012 or later).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(2) Other firm commitments result mainly from purchase obligations related to multi-year equipment supply contracts linked to the sale of businesses to third parties.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(3) Obligations related to pensions, post-retirement health and welfare benefits and postemployment benefit obligations are excluded from the table. Refer to Note 18 to our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Off-balance sheet commitments and contingencies.</I> &nbsp;On June 30, 2009, our off-balance sheet commitments and contingencies amounted to &#8364;2,267 million, consisting primarily of &#8364;1,069 million in guarantees on long-term contracts for the supply of telecommunications equipment and services by our consolidated and non-consolidated subsidiaries. Generally we provide these guarantees to back performance bonds issued to customers through financial institutions. These performance bonds and counter-guarantees are standard industry practice and are routinely provided in long-term supply contracts. If certain events occur subsequent to our including these commitments within our off-balance sheet contingencies, such as the delay in promised delivery or claims related to an alleged failure by us to perform on our long-term contracts, or the failure by one of our customers to meet its payment obligations, 
we reserve the estimated risk on our consolidated balance sheet under the line items &#8220;Provisions&#8221; or &#8220;Amounts due to/from our customers on construction contracts,&#8221; or in inventory reserves. Not included in the &#8364;2,267 million is approximately &#8364; 429 million in customer financing, as described below.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>With respect to guarantees given for contract performance, only those issued by us to back guarantees granted by financial institutions are presented in the table below.</P>

<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(1) This amount is not reduced by any amounts that may be recovered under recourse or similar provisions, guarantees received, or insurance proceeds, as explained more fully below. Of this amount, &#8364;191 million as of June 30, 2009 and &#8364;200 million as of June 30, 2008 represent undertakings we provided on contracts of non-consolidated companies.</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(2) This contingent liability relates to our obligation pursuant to the applicable law of certain jurisdictions to repurchase discounted notes receivable in certain circumstances, such as if there is a payment default.</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(3) Included in the &#8364;645 million are: &#8364;111 million of guarantees provided to tax authorities in connection with tax assessments contested by us, &#8364;150 million primarily related to secondary lease obligations resulting from leases that were assigned to businesses Lucent spun-off or disposed of and &#8364;384 million of various guarantees given by certain subsidiaries in the Group. Included in the &#8364;767 million are: &#8364;121 million of guarantees provided to tax authorities in connection with tax assessments contested by us, &#8364;90 million of commitments related to leasing or sale and leaseback transactions, &#8364;103 million primarily related to secondary lease obligations resulting from leases that were assigned to businesses Lucent spun-off or disposed of and &#8364;453 million of various guarantees given by certain subsidiaries in the Group.</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(4) Commitments related to businesses sold or contributed to Thales in 2007. Commitments that were still in the process of being transferred to Thales as of June 30, 2008, are counter-guaranteed by Thales (Thales agreed to indemnify Alcatel-Lucent for and against any payment that any Alcatel-Lucent entity is required to make pursuant to any obligation under any guarantees related to the businesses sold or contributed to Thales). </I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(5) Excluding our commitment to provide further customer financing, as described below.</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(6) The amounts in this item represent borrowings and advance payments received which are secured through security interests or similar liens granted by us. The borrowings are reflected in the Contractual Payment Obligations table above in the line item &#147;Financial debt (excluding finance leases).&#148;</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>(7) This guarantee covers any intraday debit position that could result from the daily transfers between our central treasury account and our subsidiaries&#146; accounts. </I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amounts of guarantees given on contracts reflected in the preceding table represent the maximum potential amounts of future payments (undiscounted) we could be required to make under current guarantees granted by us. These amounts do not reflect any amounts that may be recovered under recourse, collateralization provisions in the guarantees or guarantees given by customers for our benefit. In addition, most of the parent company guarantees and performance bonds given to our customers are insured; therefore, the estimated exposure related to the guarantees set forth in the preceding table may be reduced by insurance proceeds that we may receive in case of a claim.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Commitments related to product warranties and pension and post-retirement benefits are not included in the preceding table. These commitments are fully reflected in our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements. Contingent liabilities arising out of litigation, arbitration or regulatory actions are not included in the preceding table either, with the exception of those linked to the guarantees given on our long-term contracts.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Commitments related to contracts that have been cancelled or interrupted due to the default or bankruptcy of the customer are included in the above-mentioned &#147;Guarantees given on contracts made by entities within the Group and by non-consolidated subsidiaries&#148; as long as the legal release of the guarantee has not been obtained.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Guarantees given on third-party long-term contracts could require us to make payments to the guaranteed party based on a non-consolidated company&#146;s failure to perform under an agreement. The fair value of these contingent liabilities, corresponding to the premium to be received by the guarantor for issuing the guarantee, was &#8364;2 million as of June 30, 2009 and also as of June 30, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 28</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In connection with our consent solicitation to amend the indenture pursuant to which Lucent&#8217;s 2 &#190; Series A Convertible Senior Debentures due 2023 and 2 &#190; Series B Convertible Senior Debentures due 2025 were issued, on December 29, 2006 we issued a full and unconditional guaranty of these debentures. The guaranty is unsecured and is subordinated to the prior payment in full of our senior debt and is <I>pari passu</I> with our other general unsecured obligations, other than those that expressly provide that they are senior to the guaranty obligations.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Customer Financing.</I> &nbsp;Based on standard industry practice, we extend financing to certain of our customers by granting extended payment terms, making direct loans, or providing guarantees to third-party financing sources. More generally, as part of our business, we routinely enter into long-term contracts, which can involve our customers paying significant amounts over long periods of time.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As of June 30, 2009, net of reserves, we had an exposure of &#8364;&nbsp;320&nbsp;million under drawn customer financing arrangements, representing approximately &#8364;&nbsp;316&nbsp;million of deferred payments and loans, and &#8364;&nbsp;4 million of guarantees. In addition, as of this date, we had further commitments to provide customer financing for approximately &#8364;&nbsp;77&nbsp;million. It is possible that these further commitments will expire without our having to actually provide the committed financing.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Outstanding customer financing and undrawn commitments are monitored by assessing, among other things, each customer&#146;s short-term and long-term liquidity positions, the customer&#146;s current operating performance versus plan, the execution challenges faced by the customer, changes in the competitive landscape, and the customer&#146;s management experience and depth. When we detect potential problems, we take mitigating actions, which may include the cancellation of undrawn commitments. Although by taking such actions we may be able to limit the total amount of our exposure, we still may suffer losses to the extent of the drawn and guaranteed amounts. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B> <BR>
</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Lucent&#146;s Separation Agreements. </I>Lucent is party to various agreements that were entered into in connection with the separation of Lucent and former affiliates, including AT&amp;T, Avaya, LSI Corporation (formerly Agere Systems, before its merger with LSI corporation in April&nbsp;2007) and NCR Corporation. Pursuant to these agreements, Lucent and the former affiliates have agreed to allocate certain liabilities related to each other&#146;s business, and have agreed to share liabilities based on certain allocations and thresholds. We are not aware of any material liabilities to Lucent&#146;s former affiliates as a result of the separation agreements that are not otherwise reflected in our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this document. Nevertheless, it is possible that potential liabilities for which the former affiliates bear primary responsibility may lead to contributions by Lucent.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Lucent&#146;s Other Commitments &#150; Contract Manufacturers. </I>Lucent outsources most of its manufacturing operation to electronic manufacturing service (EMS) providers. Until 2008, two EMS providers, Celestica and Solectron (acquired by Flextronics in October&nbsp;2007), had exclusive arrangements with Lucent to supply most of Lucent-designed wireless and wireline products. Although no longer exclusive suppliers, Celestica continues to manufacture most of Lucent&#146;s existing wireless products and Solectron continues to consolidate the outsourced manufacturing of Lucent&#146;s portfolio of wireline products. Lucent generally does not have minimum purchase obligations in its contract-manufacturing relationships with EMS providers and therefore the contractual payment obligations schedule, presented above under the heading &#147;Contractual Obligations&#148;, does not include any commitments related to contract manufacturers.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Lucent&#146;s Guarantees and Indemnification Agreements. </I>Lucent divested certain businesses and assets through sales to third-party purchasers and spin-offs to the other common shareowners of the businesses spun-off. In connection with these transactions, certain direct or indirect indemnifications were provided to the buyers or other third parties doing business with the divested entities. These indemnifications include secondary liability for certain leases of real property and equipment assigned to the divested entity and specific indemnifications for certain legal and environmental contingencies, as well as vendor supply commitments. The durations of such indemnifications vary but are standard for transactions of this nature.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Lucent remains secondarily liable for approximately U.S.&nbsp;$&nbsp;72&nbsp;million of lease obligations as of June 30, 2009 (U.S.&nbsp;$&nbsp;119&nbsp;million of lease obligations as of June 30, 2008), that were assigned to Avaya, LSI Corporation (formerly Agere) and purchasers of other businesses that were divested. The remaining terms of these assigned leases and the corresponding guarantees range from one month to 10&nbsp;years. The primary obligor under assigned leases may terminate or restructure the lease obligation before its original maturity and thereby relieve Lucent of its secondary liability. Lucent generally has the right to receive indemnity or reimbursement from the assignees and we have not reserved for losses on this form of guarantee.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Lucent is party to a tax-sharing agreement to indemnify AT&amp;T and is liable for tax adjustments that are attributable to its lines of business, as well as a portion of certain other shared tax adjustments during the years prior to its separation from AT&amp;T. Lucent has similar agreements with Avaya and LSI Corporation. Certain proposed or assessed tax adjustments are subject to these tax-sharing agreements. We do not expect that the outcome of these other matters will have a material adverse effect on our consolidated results of operations, consolidated financial position or near-term liquidity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 29</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:2.65pt; text-indent:14.2pt; line-height:12.8pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I> <BR>
</I></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Lucent guaranty of Alcatel-Lucent public bonds. </I>On March&nbsp;27, 2007, Lucent issued full and unconditional guaranties of our 6.375% notes due 2014 (the principal amount of which was &#8364;&nbsp;462&nbsp;million on June&nbsp;30, 2009) and our 4.750% Convertible and/or Exchangeable Bonds due 2011 (the principal amount of which was &#8364;&nbsp;1,022&nbsp;million on June&nbsp;30, 2009). Each guaranty is unsecured and is subordinated to the prior payment in full of Lucent&#146;s senior debt and is <I>pari passu</I> with Lucent&#146;s other general unsecured obligations, other than those that expressly provide that they are senior to the guaranty obligations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I> <BR>
</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt;  font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Customer Credit Approval Process and Risks.</I> &nbsp;We engage in a thorough credit approval process prior to providing financing to our customers or guarantees to financial institutions, which provide financing to our customers. Any significant undertakings have to be approved by a central Trade and Project Finance group and by a central Risk Assessment Committee, each independent from our commercial departments. We continually monitor and manage the credit we have extended to our customers, and attempt to limit credit risks by, in some cases, obtaining security interests or by securitizing or transferring to banks or export credit agencies a portion of the risk associated with this financing.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:2.65pt; text-indent:14.2pt; line-height:12.8pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Although, as discussed above, we engage in a rigorous credit approval process and have taken actions to limit our exposure to customer credit risks, if economic conditions and the telecommunications industry in particular were to deteriorate, leading to the financial failure of our customers, we may realize losses on credit we extended and loans we made to our customers, on guarantees provided for our customers and losses relating to our commercial risk exposure under long-term contracts, as well as the loss of our customer's ongoing business. &nbsp;&nbsp;In such a context, should customers fail to meet their obligations to us, we may experience reduced cash flows and losses in excess of reserves, which could materially adversely impact our results of operations and financial position.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Capital Expenditures.</I> We expect to materially reduce capital expenditures in 2009 compared to the &#8364; 901 million, including capitalization of development expenditures, that was spent in 2008 (of which &#8364; 399 million during the first half 2008 and &#8364; 502 million during the second half 2008). We expect to make capital expenditures in the second half of 2009 of approximately the same amount or slightly more than what we spent in the first half of the year (&#8364;340 million for the first half 2009). We believe that our current cash and cash equivalents, cash flows and funding arrangements provide us with adequate flexibility to meet our short-term and long-term financial obligations and to pursue our capital expenditure program, as planned. We base our judgment on current and future economic and market conditions. If these conditions were to deteriorate, we could be required to engage in additional restructuring efforts beyond those a
nnounced in July 2009, and to seek additional sources of capital, which may be difficult depending on market conditions and our ability to access credit markets </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Market Risk</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Financial instruments</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Although, at June 30, 2009, our exposure to financial market risks was not materially different from our exposure at the end of last year, as described in our 2008 Form 20-F, outstanding amounts may vary significantly according to underlying exposures and fair value of derivative instruments changes depending on market conditions. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The only significant change is in the break-down of our gross financial debt between fixed rate debt and floating rate debt. As a result of our hedging transactions, the fixed rate debt part of our gross financial debt represents approximately 90 % of our total gross debt as of June 30, 2009 compared to 56% as of December 31, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As noted in our 2008 &#150; Form 20-F, we are exposed to credit risk on marketable securities, cash and cash equivalents and derivative instruments in the event of counterparty default. We closely monitor this credit risk daily remaining within strict limits based on the counterparties&#8217; credit ratings. As of today, we have not suffered any significant loss due to a counterparty default. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify> <BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR>
<BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>p. 30</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; padding-left:14.15pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Research and Development</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Cost</I>. During the first half 2009, our research and development costs amounted to &#8364; 1,345 million, including the impact of the capitalization of development costs, the capital gain (loss) on disposal of fixed assets and the impact of the purchase price allocation entries for the business combination with Lucent, as disclosed in Note&nbsp;4-b of the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this document, which represented 17.9 % of revenues of the period, compared to costs of &#8364; 1,410 million in the first half of 2008, which represented 17.7 % of the revenues for that period. Excluding the impact of the capitalization of development costs and capital gain (loss) on disposal of fixed assets and the impact of the purchase price allocation entries of the business combination with Lucent, research and development costs amounted to &#8364; 1,267 million for the first half 2009 compared with &#8364;1,2
85 million for the first half 2008.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(a) Translation of amounts from euros (&#8220;&#8364;&#8221;) into U.S. Dollars (&#8220;$&#8221;) has been made merely for the convenience of the reader at the Noon Buying Rate of &#8364;1 = $ 1.4020 on June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt">(1) Classification of share-based payments between cost of sales, administrative and selling expenses and research and development costs is provided in note 5. </P>

<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(a) Translation of amounts from euros (&#8220;&#8364;&#8221;) into U.S. Dollars (&#8220;$&#8221;) has been made merely for the convenience of the reader at the Noon Buying Rate of &#8364;1 = $ 1.4020 on June 30, 2009.</P>

<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(a) Translation of amounts from euros (&#8220;&#8364;&#8221;) into U.S. Dollars (&#8220;$&#8221;) has been made merely for the convenience of the reader at the Noon Buying Rate of &#8364;1 = $ 1.4020 on June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:11.35pt; text-indent:-11.35pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1)&nbsp;Includes &#8364; 622 million of cash and cash equivalents held in countries subject to exchange control restrictions as of June 30, 2009 (&#8364; 521 million as of June 30, 2008). Such restrictions can limit the use of such cash and cash equivalents by other group subsidiaries and the parent.</P>

<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:21.25pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1) See consolidated statements of comprehensive income.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify><B><BR>
<BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F6</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>NOTES TO UNAUDITED CONDENSED INTERIM CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Alcatel-Lucent (formerly called Alcatel) is a French public limited liability company that is subject to the French Commercial Code and to all the legal requirements governing commercial companies in France. Alcatel changed its name to Alcatel-Lucent on completion of its business combination with Lucent Technologies Inc. in 2006, Alcatel-Lucent was incorporated on June&nbsp;18,&nbsp;1898 and will be dissolved on June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2086, unless its existence is extended or shortened by shareholder vote. Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s headquarters are situated at 54, rue la Bo&#233;tie, 75008 Paris, France. Alcatel-Lucent is listed principally on the Paris and New York stock exchanges.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements reflect the results and financial position of Alcatel-Lucent and its subsidiaries (the &#147;Group&#148;) as well as its investments in associates (&#147;equity affiliates&#148;) and joint ventures. They are presented in Euros rounded to the nearest million.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Group develops and integrates technologies, applications and services to offer innovative global communications solutions.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On July 29,&nbsp;2009, the Board of Directors authorized the issuance of these condensed interim consolidated financial statements at June 30,&nbsp;2009.</P>
<P style="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:3pt; line-height:14pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:12pt; border-bottom:2.25pt solid #000000" align=justify><B>Note 1 Summary of accounting policies</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Due to the listing of Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s securities on the Euronext Paris and in accordance with the European Union&#146;s regulation No. 1606/2002 of July&nbsp;19,&nbsp;2002, the condensed interim consolidated financial statements of the Group are prepared in accordance with IFRSs (International Financial Reporting Standards), as adopted by the European Union, as of the date when our Board of Directors authorized these condensed interim consolidated financial statements for issuance.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>IFRSs can be found at: www.ec.europa.eu/internal_market/accounting/ias_en.htm#adopted-commission</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>IFRSs include the standards approved by the International Accounting Standards Board (&#147;IASB&#148;), that is, IFRSs, the International Accounting Standards (&#147;IASs&#148;) and the accounting interpretations issued by the International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee (&#147;IFRIC&#148;) or the former Standing Interpretations Committee (&#147;SIC&#148;).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The condensed interim consolidated financial statements at June 30,&nbsp;2009 are prepared in compliance with IAS 34 &#147;Interim Financial Reporting&#148;. The accounting policies and measurement principles adopted for the condensed interim consolidated financial statements at June 30,&nbsp;2009 are the same as those used in the consolidated financial statements at December 31, 2008, except the changes disclosed hereafter.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At June 30, 2009, the IFRSs adopted by the European Union were the same as International Financial Reporting Standards (including IASs and interpretations) published by the IASB, with the exception of IAS&nbsp;39, which was only partially adopted, but which has no impact on Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s financial statements.&nbsp;As a result, the Group&#146;s unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements comply with International Financial Reporting Standards as published by the IASB.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>New financial reporting standards and interpretations that the Group applies but which are not yet mandatory</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As of June 30,&nbsp;2009, Alcatel-Lucent had not applied any new International Financial Reporting Standards and Interpretations that the European Union has published and adopted but which were not yet mandatory.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>New financial reporting standards or amendments applied as of January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2009</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The IASB published amendments to IAS 1 &#147;Presentation of Financial Statements: A Revised Presentation&#148; during 2007, which were endorsed by the European Union and became effective as of January 1, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The main changes from the previous version of IAS 1 are as follows:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify>-</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">the titles &#147;balance sheet&#148; and &#147;cash flow statement&#148; are now denominated &#147;statement of financial position&#148; and &#147;statement of cash flows&#148;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify>-</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">all changes arising from transactions with owners in their capacity as owners be presented separately from non-owner changes in equity;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify>-</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">income and expenses be presented in one statement (statement of comprehensive income) or two statements (a separate income statement and a statement of comprehensive income);</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify>-</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Times New Roman" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">the total comprehensive income be presented in the financial statements.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F7</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>New financial reporting standards, amendments and interpretations published and applied by the Group as of June 30, 2009</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The IASB published the following standards and interpretations before June 30, 2009, which were endorsed by the European Union and are required to be applied as of June 30, 2009:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to IFRS 2 &#8220;Share-based Payment - Vesting Conditions and Cancellations&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendments to IAS 32 &#8220;Financial Instruments: Presentation and IAS 1 Presentation of Financial Statements&#8221; - Puttable Financial Instruments and Obligations arising on Liquidation&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">improvements to IFRSs issued by the IASB in May 2008 (except the improvements related to IFRS 5- &#8220;Non-current Assets Held For Sale and Discontinued Operations&#8221;, improvement applicable as of July 1<SUP>st,</SUP> 2009);</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendments to IFRS 1 &quot;First-time Adoption of IFRSs&quot; and IAS 27 &quot;Consolidated and Separate Financial Statements &#8211; Cost of an Investment in a Subsidiary, Jointly Controlled Entity or Associate&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to &nbsp;IFRIC 9 and IAS 39 &#8220;Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement &#8211; Embedded Derivatives&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">IFRIC 11 &#8220;Group and Treasury Share Transactions&#8221;; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">IFRIC 16 &#8220;Hedges of a Net Investment in a Foreign Operation&quot;.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>None of these new improvements to standards, amendments or interpretations had a material impact on the Group&#8217;s unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements for the six-month period ended June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>New financial reporting standards, amendments and interpretations published and mandatory but not yet endorsed by the European Union</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I><BR></I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The IASB published the following interpretations prior to June 30, 2009, which have not yet been endorsed by the European Union, but which are effective for other than European-listed companies for annual periods beginning on or after January 1<SUP>st</SUP>, 2009:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
