<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to IFRS 7 &#8220;Financial Instruments: Disclosures &#8211; Improving Disclosures about Financial Instruments&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to IFRIC 9, IAS 39 &#8220;Embedded derivatives&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to IAS 39.80 &#8220;Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement&#8221; included in Improvements to IFRS issued by the IASB in May 2008; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">IFRIC 15 &quot;Agreements for the Construction of Real Estate &quot;.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>None of these amendments or interpretations would have had a material impact on the Group&#8217;s unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements, if they had been applied.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>New financial reporting standards, amendments and interpretations published but not yet mandatory and not yet applied by the Group</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I><BR></I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The IASB published the following standards, amendments and interpretations prior to June 30, 2009, which were endorsed by the European Union, but which are not yet effective and for which the Group did not elect earlier application:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I><BR></I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">a revised IFRS 3 &#8220;Business Combinations&#8221; and an amended IAS 27 &#8220;Consolidated and Separate Financial Statements&#8221;. We intend &nbsp;to apply these revised and amended standards to business combinations for which the acquisition date is on or after the beginning of 2010;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">revised IFRS 1 &quot;First-time Adoption of IFRSs&quot; issued in November 2008;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">improvements to IFRSs (issued by the IASB in May 2008) related to IFRS 5- &#8220;Non-current Assets Held For Sale and Discontinued Operations&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendment to IAS 39 &#8220;Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement &#8211; Eligible Hedged Items&#8221;;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">improvements to IFRSs (issued by the IASB in April 2009);</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">amendments to IFRS 2 &#8220;Group Cash-settled Share-based &nbsp;Payment Transactions&#8221; issued in June 2009;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">IFRIC 17 &#8220;Distributions of Non-cash Assets to Owners&#8221;; and </FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">IFRIC 18 &#8220;Transfers of Assets from Customers&#8221;.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>None of these new revised or improvement to standards, amendments or interpretations is anticipated to have a material impact on our future consolidated financial statements except IFRS 3 revised and IAS 27 amended. These revised or amended standards could have a material impact on our future consolidated financial statements, if we were to enter into significant, new business combinations.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Transitional provisions of IFRS 3 affecting income taxes could also have a material impact on our future consolidated financial statements, since deferred tax assets recognized after completion of a business combination that had not been initially recognized will be recognized in the income statement without any related reduction of goodwill, contrary to the accounting treatment prescribed in the current IFRS 3 (see note 1n).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F8</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In this respect, significant unrecognized income tax loss carry-forwards that relate to Lucent Technologies could materially impact the Group&#146;s income statement in a positive way, if, in compliance with IAS 12 &#147;Income taxes&#148;, the Group is able to recognize deferred tax assets in the future corresponding to these tax losses.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>a/ Basis of preparation</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The condensed interim consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRSs under the historical cost convention, with the exception of certain categories of assets and liabilities. The categories concerned are detailed in the following notes.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>b/ Consolidation methods</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Companies over which the Group has control are fully consolidated.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Companies over which the Group has joint control are accounted for using proportionate consolidation.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Companies over which the Group has significant influence (investments in &#147;associates&quot; or equity affiliates) are accounted for under the equity method. Significant influence is assumed when the Group's interest in the voting rights is 20% or more.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with SIC 12 &quot;Consolidation &#150; Special purpose entities&quot;, special purpose entities (SPE) are consolidated when the substance of the relationship between the Group and the SPE indicates that the SPE is controlled by the Group.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All significant intra-Group transactions are eliminated.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>c/ Business combinations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Regulations governing first-time adoption</I></B>: Business combinations that were completed before January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004, the transition date to IFRSs, were not restated, as permitted by the optional exemption included in IFRS 1. Goodwill was therefore not recognized for business combinations occurring prior to January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004, which were previously accounted for in accordance with article 215 of Regulation No. 99-02 of the &#147;Comit&#233; de la R&#233;glementation Comptable&#148;. According to this regulation, the assets and liabilities of the acquired company are maintained at their carrying value at the date of the acquisition, adjusted for the Group's accounting policies, and the difference between this value and the acquisition cost of the shares is adjusted directly against equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Business combinations after January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004</I></B>: These business combinations are accounted for in accordance with the purchase method required by IFRS 3. Once control is obtained over a company, its assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities are measured at their fair value at the acquisition date in accordance with IFRS requirements. Any difference between the fair value and the carrying value is accounted for in the respective underlying asset or liability, including both the Group interest and non-controlling interests. Any excess between the purchase price and the Group&#146;s share in the fair value of such net assets is recognized as goodwill (see intangible and tangible assets).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>If the initial accounting for a business combination cannot be completed before the end of the annual period in which the business combination is effected, the initial accounting must be completed within twelve months of the acquisition date.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The accounting treatment of deferred taxes related to business combinations is described in note 1n below. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The accounting treatment of stock options of companies acquired in the context of a business combination is described in note 1w below.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>d/ Translation of financial statements denominated in foreign currencies</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The statements of financial position of consolidated entities having a functional currency different from the presentation currency of the Group (i.e. euro) are translated into euros at the closing exchange rate (spot exchange rate at the statement of financial position date), and the income statements and statement of cash flow of such consolidated entities are translated at the average period to date exchange rate. The resulting translation adjustments are included in equity under the caption &quot;Cumulative translation adjustments&quot;.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F9</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Goodwill and fair value adjustments arising from the acquisition of a foreign entity are considered as assets and liabilities of that entity. They are therefore expressed in the entity&#146;s functional currency and translated into euros using the closing exchange rate.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Regulations governing first-time adoption</I></B>: In accordance with the option available under IFRS 1, the accumulated total of translation adjustments at the transition date was deemed to be zero. This amount was reversed against retained earnings, leaving the amount of equity unchanged. Translation adjustments that predate the IFRS transition will therefore not be included when calculating gains or losses arising from the future disposal of consolidated subsidiaries or equity affiliates existing as of the IFRS transition date.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>e/ Translation of foreign currency transactions</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Foreign currency transactions are translated at the rate of exchange applicable on the transaction date. At period-end, foreign currency monetary assets and liabilities are translated at the rate of exchange prevailing on that date. The resulting exchange gains or losses are recorded in the income statement in &quot;other financial income (loss)&quot;.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Exchange gains or losses on foreign currency financial instruments that represent an economic hedge of a net investment in a foreign subsidiary are reported as translation adjustments in equity under the caption &quot;Cumulative translation adjustments&quot; until the disposal of the investment. Refer to note 1d above for information on the recognition of translation adjustments at the IFRS transition date.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In order for a currency derivative to be eligible for hedge accounting treatment (cash flow hedge or fair value hedge), its hedging role must be defined and documented and it must be seen to be effective for the entirety of its period of use. Fair value hedges allow companies to protect themselves against exposure to changes in fair value of their assets, liabilities or firm commitments. Cash flow hedges allow companies to protect themselves against exposure to changes in future cash flows (for example, revenues generated by the company&#8217;s assets).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The value used for derivatives is their fair value. Changes in the fair value of derivatives are accounted for as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">for derivatives treated as cash flow hedges, changes in their fair value are accounted for in equity and then transferred from equity to the income statement (cost of sales) when the hedged revenue is accounted for. The ineffective portion is recorded in &quot;other financial income (loss)&quot;.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">for derivatives treated as fair value hedges, changes in their fair value are recorded in the income statement where they offset the changes in fair value of the hedged asset, liability or firm commitment.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In addition to derivatives used to hedge firm commitments documented as fair value hedges, from April&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2005 onwards, Alcatel-Lucent has designated and documented highly probable future streams of revenue and has entered into hedge transactions with respect to such revenue. The corresponding derivatives are accounted for in accordance with the requirements governing cash flow hedge accounting.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Certain foreign exchange derivatives are not considered eligible for hedge accounting treatment, as the derivatives are not designated as hedges for cost/benefit reasons.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Derivatives related to commercial bids are not considered eligible for hedge accounting treatment and are accounted for as trading financial instruments. Changes in fair values of such instruments are included in the income statement in cost of sales (in the operating segment &#147;other&#148;).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Once a commercial contract is effective, the corresponding firm commitment is hedged with a derivative treated as a fair value hedge. Revenues made pursuant to such a contract are then accounted for, throughout the duration of the contract, using the spot rate prevailing on the date on which the contract was effective, insofar as the exchange rate hedging is effective.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>f/ Research and development expenses and other capitalized development costs</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 38 &#147;Intangible Assets&#148;, research and development expenses are recorded as expenses in the year in which they are incurred, except for:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>


<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial"><B><I>development costs</I></B>, which are capitalized as an intangible asset when the following criteria are met:</FONT></P>


<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- the project is clearly defined, and the costs are separately identified and reliably measured;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- the technical feasibility of the project is demonstrated;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- the ability to use or sell the products created during the project;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- the intention exists to finish the project and use or sell the products created during the project; </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- a potential market for the products created during the project exists or their usefulness, in case of internal use, is demonstrated, leading one to believe that the project will generate probable future economic benefits; and</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- adequate resources are available to complete the project.</P>





<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F10</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>These development costs are amortized over the estimated useful life of the projects or the products they are incorporated within. The amortization of capitalized development costs begins as soon as the related product is released.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Specifically for software, useful life is determined as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- in case of internal use: over its probable service lifetime,</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- in case of external use: according to prospects for sale, rental or other forms of distribution.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Capitalized software development costs are those incurred during the programming, codification and testing phases. Costs incurred during the design and planning, product definition and product specification stages are accounted for as expenses.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:35.45pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amortization of capitalized software costs during a reporting period is the greater of the amount computed using (a) the ratio that current gross revenues for a product bear to the total of current and anticipated future gross revenues for that product and (b) the straight-line method over the remaining estimated economic life of the software or the product it is incorporated within.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amortization of internal use software capitalized development costs is accounted for by function depending on the beneficiary function.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial"><B><I>customer design engineering costs </I></B>(recoverable amounts disbursed under the terms of contracts with customers), are included in work in progress on construction contracts.</p>


<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>With regard to business combinations, a portion of the purchase price is allocated to in-process research and development projects that may be significant. As part of the process of analyzing these business combinations, Alcatel-Lucent may make the decision to buy technology that has not yet been commercialized rather than develop the technology internally. Decisions of this nature consider existing opportunities for Alcatel-Lucent to stay at the forefront of rapid technological advances in the telecommunications-data networking industry.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The fair value of in-process research and development acquired in business combinations is usually based on present value calculations of income, an analysis of the project's accomplishments and an evaluation of the overall contribution of the project, and the project's risks.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The revenue projection used to value in-process research and development is based on estimates of relevant market sizes and growth factors, expected trends in technology, and the nature and expected timing of new product introductions by Alcatel-Lucent and its competitors. Future net cash flows from such projects are based on management's estimates of such projects&#146; cost of sales, operating expenses and income taxes.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The value assigned to purchased in-process research and development is also adjusted to reflect the stage of completion, the complexity of the work completed to date, the difficulty of completing the remaining development, costs already incurred, and the projected cost to complete the projects.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Such value is determined by discounting the net cash flows to their present value. The selection of the discount rate is based on Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s weighted average cost of capital, adjusted upward to reflect additional risks inherent in the development life cycle.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Capitalized development costs considered as assets (either generated internally and capitalized or reflected in the purchase price of a business combination) are generally amortized over 3 to 10 years.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Impairment tests are carried out using the methods described in the following paragraph.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>g/ Goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 16 &#147;Property, Plant and Equipment&#148; and with IAS 38 &#147;Intangible Assets&#148;, only items whose cost can be reliably measured and for which future economic benefits are likely to flow to the Group are recognized as assets.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 36 &#147;Impairment of Assets&#148;, whenever events or changes in market conditions indicate a risk of impairment of intangible assets and property, plant and equipment, a detailed review is carried out in order to determine whether the net carrying amount of such assets remains lower than their recoverable amount, which is defined as the greater of fair value (less costs to sell) and value in use. Value in use is measured by discounting the expected future cash flows from continuing use of the asset and its ultimate disposal. Intangible assets with indefinite useful lives (such as trade names) are tested for impairment annually.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F11</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the event that the recoverable amount is lower than the net carrying value, the difference between the two amounts is recorded as an impairment loss. Impairment losses for property, plant and equipment or intangible assets with finite useful lives can be reversed if the recoverable value becomes higher than the net carrying value (but not exceeding the loss initially recorded).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Goodwill</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Since transition to IFRSs, goodwill is no longer amortized in accordance with IFRS 3 &#147;Business Combinations&#148;. Before January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004, goodwill was amortized using the straight-line method over a period, determined on a case-by-case basis, not exceeding 20 years.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Goodwill is tested for impairment at least annually. This is done during the second quarter of the year. The impairment test methodology is based on a comparison between the recoverable amounts of each of the Group&#146;s Business Divisions (considered as the grouping of cash generating units (&quot;CGU&quot;) at which level the impairment test is performed) and the Group Business Division&#146;s net asset carrying values (including goodwill). Within Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s reporting structure, Business Divisions are one level below the four operating segments (Carrier, Applications Software, Enterprise and Services). Such recoverable amounts are mainly determined using discounted cash flows over five years and a discounted residual value.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>An additional impairment test is also performed when events indicating a potential decrease of the recoverable value of a Business Division occur. Goodwill impairment losses cannot be reversed.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Equity affiliate goodwill is included with the related investment in &#147;share in net assets of equity affiliates&#148;. The requirements of IAS 39 are applied to determine whether any impairment loss must be recognized with respect to the net investment in equity affiliates. The impairment loss is calculated according to IAS 36 requirements.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>When the reporting structure is reorganized in a way that changes the composition of one or more Business Divisions to which goodwill was allocated, a new impairment test is performed on the goodwill for which the underlying Business Divisions have changed. Such a reallocation was made in October 2007 and on January 1, 2009 using a relative value approach similar to the one used when an entity disposes of an operation within a Business Division.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Intangible assets</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Intangible assets mainly include capitalized development costs and those assets acquired in business combinations, being primarily acquired technologies or customer relationships. Intangible assets, other than trade names, are generally amortized on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives (i.e. 3 to 10 years). However, software amortization methods may be adjusted to take into account how the product is marketed. Amortization is classified as part of cost of sales, research and development costs (acquired technology, IPR&amp;D, etc.) or administrative and selling expenses (customer relationships), depending on the designation of the asset. Impairment losses are accounted for in a similar manner or in restructuring costs if they occur as part of a restructuring plan or on a specific line item if very material (refer to note 1p). In Process R&amp;D amortization begins once technical feasibility is reached. Certain trade names are considered
 to have indefinite useful lives and therefore are not amortized.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Capital gain/loss of intangible assets are accounted for in the corresponding cost line items in the income statement depending of the nature of the underlying asset (i.e. cost of sales, administrative and selling expenses or research and development costs).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Property, plant and equipment</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Property, plant and equipment are valued at historical cost for the Group less accumulated depreciation expenses and any impairment losses. Depreciation expense is generally calculated over the following useful lives: </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD valign=top width=534.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>. buildings and building improvements</P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=154.733><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>5-50 years</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=534.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>. infrastructure and fixtures</P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=154.733><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>5-20 years</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=534.867><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>. plant and equipment</P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=154.733><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>1-10 years</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Depreciation expense is determined using the straight-line method.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Assets acquired through finance lease arrangements or long-term rental arrangements that transfer substantially all the risks and rewards associated with ownership of the asset to the Group (tenant) are capitalized.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Residual value, if considered to be significant, is included when calculating the depreciable amount. Property, plant and equipment are segregated into their separate components if there is a significant difference in their expected useful lives, and depreciated accordingly.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F12</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Depreciation and impairment losses are accounted for in the income statement under cost of sales, research and development costs or administrative and selling expenses, depending on the nature of the asset or in restructuring costs if they occur as part of a restructuring plan or on a specific line item if very material (see note 1p).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In addition, capital gains/losses from disposal of property, plant and equipment are accounted for in the corresponding cost line items in the income statement depending of the nature of the underlying asset (i.e. cost of sales, administrative and selling expenses or research and development costs).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>h/ Non-consolidated investments and other non-current financial assets</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 39 &#147;Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement&#148;, investments in non-consolidated companies are classified as available-for-sale and therefore measured at their fair value. The fair value for listed securities is their market price. If a reliable fair value cannot be established, securities are valued at cost. Fair value changes are accounted for directly in equity. When objective evidence of impairment of a financial asset exists (for instance, a significant or prolonged decline in the value of an asset), an irreversible impairment loss is recorded. This loss can only be released upon the sale of the securities concerned.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Loans are measured at amortized cost and are subject to impairment losses if there is objective evidence of a loss in value. The impairment represented by the difference between net carrying amount and recoverable value is recognized in the income statement and can be reversed if recoverable value rises in the future. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The portfolio of non-consolidated securities and other financial assets is assessed at each quarter-end for objective evidence of impairment. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>i/ Inventories and work in progress</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Inventories and work in progress are valued at the lower of cost (including indirect production costs where applicable) or net realizable value. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net realizable value is the estimated sales revenue for a normal period of activity less expected selling costs.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>j/ Treasury stock</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Treasury shares owned by Alcatel-Lucent or its subsidiaries are valued at cost and are deducted from equity. Proceeds from the sale of such shares are recognized directly in equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>k/ Pension and retirement obligations and other employee and post-employment benefit obligations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with the laws and practices of each country where Alcatel-Lucent is established, the Group participates in employee benefit plans.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For defined contribution plans, the Group expenses contributions as and when they are due. As the Group is not liable for any legal or constructive obligations under the plans beyond the contributions paid, no provision is made. Provisions for defined benefit plans and other long-term employee benefits are determined as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">using the Projected Unit Credit Method (with projected final salary), each period of service gives rise to an additional unit of benefit entitlement and each unit is measured separately to calculate the final obligation. Actuarial assumptions such as mortality rates, rates of employee turnover and projection of future salary levels are used to calculate the obligation;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">the &#8220;corridor&#8221; method is no longer used from January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007 (see below).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The service cost is recognized in &#147;income from operating activities&#148; and the interest cost and expected return on plan assets are recognized in &#147;financial income (loss)&#148;. The impact of plan amendments is presented on a specific line item of the income statement if material (see note 1p).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Prepaid pension costs cannot exceed the net total present value of any available refund from the plan or reduction in future contributions to the plan. The use of excess pension plan assets to fund retiree healthcare for formerly represented retirees is considered a refund from the related plan. In particular, under Section 420 of the Internal Revenue Code in the United States of America as amended by the Pension Protection Act of 2006, Alcatel-Lucent can use excess pension plan assets applicable to formerly represented retirees to fund the retiree healthcare plan for such retirees until 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As of January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, the Group has elected the option provided for in the amendment of IAS 19 &#147;Employee Benefits &#150; Actuarial Gains and Losses, Group Plans and Disclosures&#148; (paragraphs 93A to 93D) that allows for the immediate recognition of actuarial gains and losses and any adjustments arising from asset ceiling limitations, net of deferred tax effects, outside of the income statement in the statement of comprehensive income.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F13</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Regulations governing first-time adoption</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with the option available under IFRS 1, the accumulated unrecognized actuarial gains and losses at the transition date were recorded in equity. Before the change in accounting method, which was retroactively applied from January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2005, the corridor method had been applied starting January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Certain other post-employment benefits such as life insurance and health insurance (particularly in the United States) or long-service medals (bonuses awarded to employees for extended service particularly in France and Germany), are also recognized as provisions, which are determined by means of an actuarial calculation similar to the one used for retirement provisions.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The accounting treatment used for employee stock options is detailed in note 1w below. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>l/ Provisions for restructuring and restructuring costs</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Provisions for restructuring costs are made when restructuring programs have been finalized and approved by Group management and have been announced and committed before the statement of financial position date of the Group's financial statements, resulting in an obligating event of the Group to third parties. Such costs primarily relate to severance payments, early retirement, costs for notice periods not worked, training costs of terminated employees, costs linked to the closure of facilities or the discontinuance of product lines and any costs arising from plans that materially change the scope of the business undertaken by the Group or the manner in which such business is conducted. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Other costs (removal costs, training costs of transferred employees, etc) and write-offs of fixed assets, inventories, work in progress and other assets, directly linked to restructuring measures, are also accounted for in restructuring costs in the income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amounts reserved for anticipated payments made in the context of restructuring programs are valued at their present value in cases where the settlement date is beyond the normal operating cycle of the company and the time value of money is deemed to be significant. The impact of the passage of time on the present value of the payments is included in other financial income (loss).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>m/ Financial debt &#150; compound financial instruments </B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Certain financial instruments contain both a liability and an equity component, including bonds that can be converted into or exchanged for new or existing shares and notes mandatorily redeemable for new or existing shares. The different components of compound financial instruments are accounted for in equity and in bonds and notes issued according to their classification, as defined in IAS 32 &#147;Financial Instruments: Disclosure and Presentation&#148;. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For instruments issued by historical Alcatel, the financial liability component was valued on the issuance date at the present value (taking into account the credit risk at issuance date) of the future cash flows (including interest and repayment of the nominal value) of a bond with the same characteristics (maturity, cash flows) but without any equity component. The portion included in equity is equal to the difference between the debt issue amount and the financial liability component. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The financial liability component of Lucent&#146;s convertible bonds was computed at present value on the business combination closing date, using the method as described in the preceding paragraph, taking into account the contractual maturity dates. The difference between the fair value of the convertible bonds and the corresponding financial liability component was accounted for in equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 32, AG33 and AG34 requirements, the consideration paid in connection with an early redemption of a compound financial instrument is allocated at the date of redemption between the liability and the equity components with an allocation method consistent with the method used initially. The amount of gain or loss relating to the liability component is recognized in &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148; and the amount of consideration relating to the equity component is recognized in equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><BR></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>n/ Deferred taxation and penalties on tax claims</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Deferred taxes are computed in accordance with the liability method for all temporary differences arising between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts, including the reversal of entries recorded in individual accounts of subsidiaries solely for tax purposes. All amounts resulting from changes in tax rates are recorded in equity or in net income (loss) for the year in which the tax rate change is enacted.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F14</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Deferred tax assets are recorded in the consolidated statement of financial position when it is probable that the tax benefit will be realized in the future. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are not discounted.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>To assess the ability of the Group to recover deferred tax assets, the following factors are taken into account:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">existence of deferred tax liabilities that are expected to generate taxable income, or limit tax deductions upon reversal,</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">forecasts of future tax results,</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">the impact of non-recurring costs included in income or loss in recent years that are not expected to be repeated in the future,</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">historical data concerning recent years&#8217; tax results, and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">if required, tax planning strategy, such as the planned disposal of undervalued assets.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As a result of a business combination, an acquirer may consider it probable that it will recover its own deferred tax assets that were not recognized before the business combination. For example, an acquirer may be able to utilize the benefit of its unused tax losses against the future taxable profit of the acquiree. In such cases, the acquirer recognizes a deferred tax asset, but does not include it as part of the accounting for the business combination, and therefore does not take it into account in determining the goodwill or the amount of any excess of the acquirer&#146;s interest in the net fair value of the acquiree&#146;s identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities over the cost of the combination.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>If the potential benefit of the acquiree&#146;s income tax loss carry-forwards or other deferred tax assets does not satisfy the criteria in IFRS 3 for separate recognition when a business combination is initially accounted for, but is subsequently realized, the acquirer will recognize the resulting deferred tax income in the income statement. If any initially unrecognized deferred tax assets related to the business combination with Lucent are recognized in future financial statements of the combined company, the impact will be accounted for in the income statement (for the tax losses not yet recognized related to both historical Alcatel and Lucent entities).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Penalties recognized on tax claims are accounted for in the &#147;income tax&#148; line item in the consolidated income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>o/ Revenues</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues include net sales and service revenues from the Group&#146;s principal business activities and income due from licensing fees and from income grants, net of value added taxes (VAT).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Most of the Group&#146;s sales are generated from complex contractual arrangements that require significant revenue recognition judgments, particularly in the areas of the sale of goods and equipment with related services constituting multiple-element arrangements, construction contracts and contracts including software. Judgment is also needed in assessing the collectibility of corresponding receivables.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues from the sale of goods and equipment are recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement with the customer exists, delivery has occurred, the significant risks and rewards of ownership of a product have been transferred to the customer, the amount of revenue can be measured reliably and it is probable that the economic benefits associated with the transaction will flow to the Group. For arrangements in which the customer specifies formal acceptance of the goods, equipment, services or software, revenue is generally deferred until all the acceptance criteria have been met.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenues from contracts with multiple-element arrangements, such as those including products with installation and integration services, are recognized as the revenue for each unit of accounting is earned based on the relative fair value of such unit, as determined by internal or third-party analyses of market-based prices. A delivered element is considered a separate unit of accounting if it has value to the customer on a standalone basis, there is objective and reliable evidence of the fair value of the undelivered elements in the arrangement, and delivery or performance of the undelivered elements is considered probable and substantially under the Group&#146;s control. If these criteria are not met, revenue for the arrangement as a whole is accounted for as a single unit of accounting in accordance with the criteria described in the preceding paragraph. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Under IAS 11, construction contracts are defined as contracts specifically negotiated for the construction of an asset or a combination of assets that are closely interrelated or interdependent in terms of their design, technology and function or their ultimate purpose of use (primarily those related to customized network solutions and network build-outs with a duration of more than two quarters). For revenues generated from construction contracts, the Group applies the percentage of completion method of accounting in application of the above principles, provided certain specified conditions are met, based either on the achievement of contractually defined milestones or on costs incurred compared with total estimated costs. Any probable construction contract losses are recognized immediately in cost of sales. If uncertainty exists regarding customer acceptance, or the contract&#146;s duration is relatively short, revenues are recognized only to the exten
t of costs incurred that are recoverable, or on completion of the contract. Construction contract costs are recognized as incurred when the outcome of a construction contract cannot be estimated reliably. In this situation, revenues are recognized only to the extent of the costs incurred that are probable of recovery. Work in progress on construction contracts is stated at production cost, excluding administrative and selling expenses. Changes in provisions for penalties for delayed delivery or poor contract execution are reported in revenues and not in cost of sales.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F15</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Advance payments received on construction contracts, before corresponding work has been carried out, are recorded in customers&#146; deposits and advances. Costs incurred to date plus recognized profits less the sum of recognized losses (in the case of provisions for contract losses) and progress billings are determined on a contract-by-contract basis. If the amount is positive, it is included as an asset under &#147;amount due from customers on construction contracts&#148;. If the amount is negative, it is included as a liability under &#147;amount due to customers on construction contracts&#148;.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the absence of a specific guidance in IAS 18 &quot;Revenue&quot;, software revenue recognition rules, as prescribed by the SOP 97-2 of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, or &#147;AICPA&#148; are applied for revenues generated from licensing, selling or otherwise marketing software solutions when the software is sold on a standalone basis. When the software is embedded with the Group&#146;s hardware and the software is considered more than incidental, guidance given in the AICPA's SOP 97-2 is generally applied with limited exceptions, such as determining fair value using methods other than vendor-specific objective evidence (VSOE) of fair value, if deferring revenue related to the delivered elements due to the impossibility of determining VSOE of an undelivered element is not considered as IFRS compliant (i.e. IFRSs do not require VSOE of fair value). If VSOE of fair value or fair value of an undelivered element cannot be determine
d or any undelivered element is essential to the functionality of the delivered element, revenue is deferred until either such criteria are met or the last element is delivered, or revenue is deferred and recognized ratably over the service period if the last undelivered element is a service.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For arrangements to sell services only, revenue from training or consulting services is recognized when the services are performed. Maintenance service revenue, including post-contract customer support, is deferred and recognized ratably over the contracted service period. Revenue from other services is generally recognized at the time of performance.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For product sales made through retailers and distributors, assuming all other revenue recognition criteria have been met, revenue is recognized upon shipment to the distribution channel, if such sales are not contingent on the distributor selling the product to third parties and the distribution contracts contain no right of return. Otherwise, revenue is recognized when the reseller or distributor sells the product to the end user.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Product rebates or quantity discounts are deducted from revenues, even in the case of promotional activities giving rise to free products.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Revenue in general is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or to be received. Where a deferred payment has a significant impact on the calculation of fair value, it is accounted for by discounting future payments.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The assessment of the ability to collect is critical in determining whether revenue or expense should be recognized. As part of the revenue recognition process, the Group assesses whether it is probable that economic benefits associated with the transaction will flow to the Group. If the Group is uncertain as to whether economic benefits will flow to the Group, revenue is deferred and recognized on a cash basis. However, if uncertainty arises about the ability to collect an amount already included in revenue, the amount in respect of which recovery has ceased to be probable is recognized as an expense in &#147;cost of sales&#148;.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>p/ Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments and income (loss) from operating activities</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Alcatel-Lucent has considered it relevant to the understanding of the Group&#146;s financial performance to present on the face of the income statement a subtotal inside the income (loss) from operating activities.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>This subtotal, named &#147;Income (loss) from operating activities before restructuring costs, impairment of assets, gain/(loss) on disposal of consolidated entities and post-retirement benefit plan amendments&#148;, excludes those elements that are difficult to predict due to their nature, frequency and/or materiality.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Those elements can be divided in two categories:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Elements that are both very infrequent and material, such as a major impairment of an asset, a disposal of investments, the settlement of litigation having a material impact or a major amendment of a pension or other post-retirement plan.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F16</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Elements that are by nature unpredictable in their amount and/or in their frequency, if they are material. Alcatel-Lucent considers that materiality must be assessed not only by comparing the amount concerned with the income (loss) from operating activities of the period, but also in terms of changes in the item from one period to another. For example, restructuring charges have shown significant changes from one period to another. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Income (loss) from operating activities includes gross margin, administrative and selling expenses and research and development costs (see note 1f) and, in particular, pension costs (except for the financial component, see note 1k), employee profit sharing, fair value changes of derivative instruments related to commercial bids, valuation allowances on receivables (including the two categories of vendor financing as described in note 1v) and capital gains (losses) from the disposal of intangible assets and property, plant and equipment, and all other operating expenses or income regardless of their predictive value in terms of nature, frequency and/or materiality.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Income (loss) from operating activities is calculated before financial income (loss), which includes the financial component of retirement expenses, financing costs and capital gains (losses) from disposal of financial assets (shares in a non-consolidated company or company consolidated under the equity method and other non-current financial assets, net), and before reduction of goodwill related to realized unrecognized income tax loss carry forwards, share in net income (losses) of equity affiliates and income (loss) from discontinued operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>q/ Finance costs and other financial income (loss)</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Finance costs include interest charges and interest income relating to net consolidated debt, which consists of bonds, the liability component of compound financial instruments such as OCEANE and other convertible bonds, other long-term debt (including lease-financing liabilities), all cash and similar items (cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities) and the changes in fair values of marketable securities accounted for at fair value through the income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Borrowing costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of an asset are capitalized as part of the cost of that asset.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>When tax law requires interest to be paid (received) on an underpayment (overpayment) of income taxes, this interest is accounted for in the &quot;other financial income (loss)&quot; line item in the consolidated income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>r/ Structure of consolidated statement of financial position</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Most of the Group's activities in the various business segments have long-term operating cycles. As a result, the consolidated statement of financial position combines current assets (including other inventories and work in progress and trade receivables and other receivables) and current liabilities (including other provisions, customers' deposits and advances, trade payables and other payables) without distinction between the amounts due within one year and those due after one year.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>s/ Financial instruments and derecognition of financial assets</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Financial instruments</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Group uses financial instruments to manage and reduce its exposure to fluctuations in interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates and commodities.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The accounting policies applied to currency hedge-related instruments are detailed in note 1e. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Financial instruments for interest rate hedges are subject to fair value hedge accounting. Financial liabilities hedged using interest rate swaps are measured at the fair value of the obligation linked to interest rate movements. Fair value changes are recorded in the income statement for the year and are offset by equivalent changes in the interest rate swaps for the effective part of the hedge.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Derecognition of financial assets</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>A financial asset as defined under IAS 32 &#147;Financial Instruments: Disclosure and Presentation&#148; is totally derecognized (removed from the statement of financial position) when, for instance, the Group expects no further cash flow to be generated by it and transfers substantially all risks and rewards attached to it.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the case of trade receivables, a transfer without recourse in case of payment default by the debtor is regarded as a transfer of substantially all risks and rewards of ownership, thus making such receivables eligible for derecognition, on the basis that risk of late payment is considered marginal. A more restrictive interpretation of the concept of &#147;substantial transfer of risks and rewards&#148; could put into question the accounting treatment that has been adopted. The amount of receivables sold without recourse is given in note&nbsp;13.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F17</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>t/ Cash and cash equivalents</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 7 &#147;Statement of Cash Flow&#148;, cash and cash equivalents in the consolidated statements of cash flows include cash (cash funds) and cash equivalents (term deposits and short-term investments that are very liquid and readily convertible to known amounts of cash and are only subject to negligible risks of changes in value). Cash and cash equivalents in the statement of cash flows do not include investments in listed securities, investments with an initial maturity date exceeding three months and without an early exit clause, or bank accounts restricted in use, other than restrictions due to regulations applied in a specific country (exchange controls) or sector of activities.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Bank overdrafts are considered as financing and are also excluded from cash and cash equivalents.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Cash and cash equivalents in the consolidated statements of financial position correspond to the cash and cash equivalents defined above.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>u/ Marketable securities</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Marketable securities are quoted market funds with original maturities exceeding three months and/or with underlying assets such as listed shares. In accordance with IAS 39 &#147;Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement&#148;, marketable securities are valued at their fair value. No securities are classified as &#147;held-to-maturity&#148;. For securities designated as financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, changes in fair value are recorded in the income statement (in finance costs). For available-for-sale securities, changes in fair value are recorded in equity, or in the income statement (other financial income (loss)), if there is objective evidence of a more than temporary decline in the fair value, or in connection with a disposal of such securities.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>v/ Customer financing</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Group undertakes two types of customer financing:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">financing relating to the operating cycle and directly linked to actual contracts;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">longer-term financing (beyond the operating cycle) through customer loans, minority investments or other forms of financing.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Both categories of financing are accounted for in &quot;Other current or non-current assets, net&quot;.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Changes in these two categories of assets are included in cash flows from operating activities in the consolidated statement of cash flows. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Furthermore, the Group may give guarantees to banks in connection with customer financing. These are included in commitments that are not in the statement of financial position.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>w/ Stock options</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with the requirements of IFRS 2 &#147;Share-based Payment&#148;, stock options granted to employees are included in the financial statements using the following principles: the stock option&#146;s fair value, which is considered to be a reflection of the fair value of the services provided by the employee in exchange for the option, is determined on the grant date.
