It is accounted for in additional paid-in capital (credit) at grant date, with a counterpart in deferred compensation (debit) (also included in additional paid-in capital). During the vesting period, deferred compensation is amortized in the income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Stock option fair value is calculated at grant date (i.e. date of approval of the plan by the Board of Directors) using the Cox-Ross-Rubinstein binomial model. This model permits consideration of the option&#146;s characteristics, such as exercise price and expiry date, market data at the time of issuance, the interest rate on risk-free securities, share price, expected volatility at grant date and expected dividends, and behavioral factors of the beneficiary, such as expected early exercise. It is considered that a beneficiary will exercise his/her option once the potential gain becomes higher than 50% of the exercise price.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Only options issued after November&nbsp;7,&nbsp;2002 and not fully vested at January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2005 and those issued after January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2005 are accounted for according to IFRS 2.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The impact of applying IFRS 2 on net income (loss) is accounted for in &#147;cost of sales&#148;, &#147;research and development costs&#148; or &#147;administrative and selling expenses&#148; depending on the functions of the beneficiaries. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F18</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Outstanding stock options at the acquisition date of a company acquired by Alcatel-Lucent in a business combination are usually converted into options to purchase Alcatel-Lucent shares using the same exchange ratio as for the acquired shares of the target company. In accordance with IFRS 3 &#147;Business Combinations&#148; and IFRS 2 &#147;Share-based Payment&#148; requirements, the fair value of stock options acquired at the time of acquisition is accounted for in the caption &#147;additional paid-in capital&#148;. Unvested options at the acquisition date are accounted for at their fair value as deferred compensation in equity (included in additional paid-in capital). The sum of these two amounts (fair value of outstanding stock options less deferred compensation), equivalent to the fair value of vested options, is taken into account in the cost of the business combination.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Only acquisitions made after January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2004 and for which unvested stock options as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2004 existed at the acquisition date are accounted for as described above.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>x/ Assets held for sale and discontinued operations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>A non-current asset or disposal group (group of assets or a cash generating unit) to be sold is considered as held for sale if its carrying amount will be recovered through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use. For this to be the case, the asset must be available for sale and its sale must be highly probable. These assets or disposal groups classified as held for sale are measured at the lower of carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>A discontinued operation is a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations for the Group that is either being sold or is being held for sale. The net income (loss) and statement of cash flow elements relating to such discontinued operations are presented in specific captions in the consolidated financial statements for all periods presented.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>y/ Condensed interim consolidated financial statements</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Seasonal nature of activity</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Interim net sales and income from operations are highly seasonal due to a high level of activity during the last quarter of the year, particularly in December. This characteristic varies from year to year. Pursuant to the IFRS accounting principles, interim net sales are accounted for under the same principles as year-end net sales; that is, in the period in which they are achieved.</P>
<P style="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:3pt; line-height:14pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:12pt; border-bottom:2.25pt solid #000000" align=justify><B>Note 2 Principal uncertainties regarding the use of estimates</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The preparation of condensed interim consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRSs requires that the Group make a certain number of estimates and assumptions that are considered realistic and reasonable. In the context of the current global economic environment, the degree of volatility and subsequent lack of visibility remains particularly high as of June 30, 2009. The preparation of interim financial reports also requires a greater use of estimates than annual reports. Subsequent facts and circumstances could lead to changes in these estimates or assumptions, which would affect the Group&#146;s financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>a/ Valuation allowance for inventories and work in progress</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Inventories and work in progress are measured at the lower of cost or net realizable value. Valuation allowances for inventories and work in progress are calculated based on an analysis of foreseeable changes in demand, technology or the market, in order to determine obsolete or excess inventories and work in progress.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The valuation allowances are accounted for in cost of sales or in restructuring costs depending on the nature of the amounts concerned. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=373.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=310.667 colspan=2><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>

</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F19</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>b/ Impairment of customer receivables</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>An impairment loss is recorded for customer receivables if the present value of the future receipts is below the nominal value. The amount of the impairment loss reflects both the customers&#146; ability to honor their debts and the age of the debts in question. A higher default rate than estimated or the deterioration of Alcatel-Lucent major customers&#146; creditworthiness could have an adverse impact on Alcatel-Lucent future results.</P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=373.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=310.8 colspan=2><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=373.467>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=147.933><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>June 30, 2009</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=162.867><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>December 31, 2008</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=373.467><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial">Accumulated impairment losses on customer receivables</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=147.933><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(206)</P>

<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>c/ Capitalized development costs, other intangible assets and goodwill</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Capitalized development costs </I></B></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=370.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=313.667 colspan=2><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=370.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=144.267><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>June 30, 2009</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=169.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>December 31, 2008</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=370.6><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial">Capitalized development costs, net</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=144.267><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>560</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=169.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>578</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The criteria for capitalizing development costs are set out in note 1f. Once capitalized, these costs are amortized over the estimated lives of the products concerned (3 to 10 years).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Group must therefore evaluate the commercial and technical feasibility of these development projects and estimate the useful lives of the products resulting from the projects. Should a product fail to substantiate these assumptions, the Group may be required to impair or write off some of the capitalized development costs in the future.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>An impairment loss of &#8364; 16 million on capitalized development costs has been accounted for during the first six months of 2009. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Impairment losses for capitalized development costs of &#8364;&nbsp;135 million were accounted for in the fourth quarter of 2008 mainly related to a change in our WiMAX strategy, by focusing on supporting fixed and nomadic broadband access applications for providers. This impairment is presented on the specific line item &#147;Impairment of assets&#148; in the income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>No impairment loss was accounted for during the first six months of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Other intangible assets and goodwill</I></B></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=412.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=271.667 colspan=2><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=412.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=115.667><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>June 30, 2009</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=156><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>December 31, 2008</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD width=412.6><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial">Goodwill, net</P>
</TD><TD width=115.667><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>4,202</P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=156><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>4,215</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=412.6><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial">Intangible assets, net <SUP>(1)</SUP></P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=115.667><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>2,385</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=156><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>2,567</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=412.6><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Total</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=115.667><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>6,587</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=156><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>6,782</B></P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1) Including capitalized development costs.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Goodwill amounting to &#8364;&nbsp;8,051 million and intangible assets amounting to &#8364;&nbsp;4,813 million were accounted for in 2006 as a result of the Lucent business combination, using market-related information, estimates (primarily based on risk adjusted discounted cash flows derived from Lucent&#8217;s management) and judgment (in particular in determining the fair values relating to the intangible assets acquired).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>No impairment loss was accounted for during the first six months of 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Impairment losses of &#8364;&nbsp;4,545 million were accounted for in 2008 (of which an impairment loss of &#8364; 810 million, related to CDMA was accounted for as of June 30, 2008) mainly related to the CDMA (&#8364;&nbsp;2,533 million), Optics (&#8364;&nbsp;1,019 million), Multicore (&#8364;&nbsp;300 million) and Applications (&#8364;&nbsp;339&nbsp;million) business divisions, which are considered to be our groups of Cash Generating Units (&#147;CGU&#148;) at which impairment tests of goodwill are performed.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The recoverable value of each business division is calculated based upon a five year discounted cash flow approach plus a discounted residual value, corresponding to the weighted average of the following three approaches:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">capitalization to perpetuity of the normalized cash flows of year 5 (Gordon Shapiro approach) &#8211; weighted 50%,</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">application of a Sales Multiple (Enterprise Value-&#8220;EV&#8221;/Sales) &#8211; weighted 25%,</FONT></P>
<P style=" margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">application of an Operating Profit Multiple (Enterprise Value-&#147;EV&#148;/Earning Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortization-&#147;EBITDA&#148;) &#150;weighted 25%.</FONT></P>



<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-21.3pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F20</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-21.3pt;" align=justify></P>
<br>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The recoverable values of our goodwill and intangible assets, as determined for the 2009 annual impairment test performed by the Group in the second quarter of 2009, are based on key assumptions which could have a significant impact on the consolidated financial statements. These key assumptions include among others the following elements:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- discount rate; and</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:42.55pt; text-indent:-7.1pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- projected cash-flows arising out of the successful implementation of the strategic plan the Group publicly announced on December 12, 2008 and on a nominal rate of growth of our revenues in 2010.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The discount rate used for the annual impairment tests of 2009 and 2008 was the Group&#146;s weighted average cost of capital (&#147;WACC&#148;) of 11% and 10% respectively. For the additional impairment test performed during the fourth quarter 2008, the rate used was 12%. These discount rates are after-tax rates applied to after-tax cash flows. The use of such rates results in recoverable values that are identical to those that would be obtained by using, as required by IAS 36, pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows. Given the absence of comparable &#147;pure player&#148; listed companies for each group of Cash Generating Units, we do not believe that the assessment of a specific WACC for each product or market is feasible. A single discount rate has therefore been used on the basis that risks specific to certain products or markets have been reflected in determining the cash flows. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Holding all other assumptions constant, a 0.5% increase or decrease in the discount rate would have decreased or increased the 2009 recoverable values of goodwill and intangible assets by &#8364; 373 million and &#8364; 406 million, respectively. An increase of 0.5% in the discount rate would not have impacted impairment losses as of June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As indicated in note 1g, in addition to the annual goodwill impairment tests, impairment tests are carried out if Alcatel-Lucent has indications of a potential reduction in the value of its goodwill or intangible assets. Possible impairments are based on discounted future cash flows and/or fair values of the assets concerned. Changes in the market conditions or the cash flows initially estimated can therefore lead to a review and a change in the impairment losses previously recorded.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>d/ Impairment of property, plant and equipment</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IAS 36 &#147;Impairment of Assets&#148;, when events or changes in market conditions indicate that tangible or intangible assets may be impaired, such assets are reviewed in detail to determine whether their carrying value is lower than their recoverable value, which could lead to recording an impairment loss (recoverable value is the higher of value in use and fair value less costs to sell) (see note 1g). Value in use is estimated by calculating the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from the asset. Fair value less costs to sell is based on the most reliable information available (market statistics, recent transactions, etc.).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>When determining recoverable values of property, plant and equipment, assumptions and estimates are made, based primarily on market outlooks, obsolescence and sale or liquidation disposal values. Any change in these assumptions can have a significant effect on the recoverable amount and could lead to a revision of recorded impairment losses.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>No impairment loss on property, plant and equipment was accounted for during the first six months of 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The planned closing of certain facilities, additional reductions in personnel and unfavorable market conditions have been considered impairment triggering events in prior years. Impairment losses of &#8364;&nbsp;34 million were recorded on property, plant and equipment in 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>e/ Provision for warranty costs and other product sales reserves</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Provisions are recorded for (i) warranties given to customers on Alcatel-Lucent products, (ii) expected losses at completion and (iii) penalties incurred in the event of failure to meet contractual obligations. These provisions are calculated based on historical return rates and warranty costs expensed as well as on estimates. These provisions and subsequent changes to the provisions are recorded in cost of sales either when revenue is recognized (provision for customer warranties) or, for construction contracts, when revenue and expenses are recognized by reference to the stage of completion of the contract activity. Costs and penalties ultimately paid can differ considerably from the amounts initially reserved and could therefore have a significant impact on future results.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F21</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR>
<BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:21.25pt; text-indent:-21.25pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1) See note 13, included in the amounts due to/from customers on construction contracts</P>

<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For further information on the impact on the income statement of changes in these provisions, see notes 13 and 16.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>f/ Deferred taxes</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Deferred tax assets relate primarily to tax loss carry-forwards and to deductible temporary differences between reported amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities. The assets relating to the tax loss carry-forwards are recognized if it is probable that the Group will generate future taxable profits against which these tax losses can be set off.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=384.8>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#FFFFFF; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=299.467 colspan=3><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>(In millions of euros)</P>
</TD></TR>

</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>June 30, 2009</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>December 31, 2008</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=16.667>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>182 <SUP>(1)</SUP></P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>339</P>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=16.667><P style="margin:0pt; line-height:11pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" align=justify><SUP>(2)</SUP></P>

<TR><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=384.8><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Related to other tax jurisdictions </P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>180</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>174</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=16.667>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=384.8><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Total</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:11.35pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>857</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=141.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>852</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=16.667>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:2pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1) Following the performance of the 2009 annual goodwill impairment test, a reassessment of deferred taxes resulted in reducing the deferred tax assets recorded in the United States and increasing those recognized in France compared to the situation as of December 31, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:14.2pt; text-indent:-14.2pt; line-height:10pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(2) Following the performance of an additional impairment test of goodwill during the fourth quarter of 2008, a reassessment of deferred taxes resulted in the reduction of deferred tax assets recorded in the United States and in France compared to the situation as of June 30, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Evaluation of the Group&#146;s capacity to utilize tax loss carry-forwards relies on significant judgment. The Group analyzes past events and the positive and negative elements of certain economic factors that may affect its business in the foreseeable future to determine the probability of its future utilization of these tax loss carry-forwards, which also consider the factors indicated in note 1n. This analysis is carried out regularly in each tax jurisdiction where significant deferred tax assets are recorded.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>If future taxable results are considerably different from those forecast that support recording deferred tax assets, the Group will be obliged to revise downwards or upwards the amount of the deferred tax assets, which would have a significant impact on Alcatel-Lucent's statement of financial position and net income (loss).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As a result of the business combination with Lucent, &#8364;&nbsp;2,395 million of net deferred tax liabilities were recorded as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2006, resulting from the temporary differences generated by the differences between the fair value of assets and liabilities acquired (mainly intangible assets such as acquired technologies) and their corresponding tax bases. These deferred tax liabilities will be reduced in the future Group income statements as and when such differences are amortized. The remaining deferred tax liabilities related to the purchase price allocation of Lucent as of June 30,&nbsp;2009 are &#8364; 820 million (&#8364; 957 million as of December 31, 2008).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As prescribed by IFRSs, Alcatel-Lucent had a twelve-month period to complete the purchase price allocation and to determine whether certain deferred tax assets related to the carry-forward of Lucent&#8217;s unused tax losses that had not been recognized in Lucent's historical financial statements should be recognized in Alcatel-Lucent's financial statements. If any additional deferred tax assets attributed to the combined company&#146;s unrecognized tax losses existing as of the transaction date are recognized in future financial statements, the tax benefit will be included in the income statement.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>g/ Pension and retirement obligations and other employee and post-employment benefit obligations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Alcatel-Lucent's results of operations include the impact of significant pension and post-retirement benefits that are measured using actuarial valuations. Inherent in these valuations are key assumptions, including assumptions about discount rates, expected return on plan assets, healthcare cost trend rates and expected participation rates in retirement healthcare plans. These assumptions are updated on an annual basis at the beginning of each fiscal year or more frequently upon the occurrence of significant events. In addition, discount rates are updated quarterly for those plans for which changes in this assumption would have a material impact on Alcatel-Lucent's results or equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F22</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=414.733>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=131.933><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>Six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2009</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=11.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=107.4><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>Six months ended June&nbsp;30,</B>&nbsp;<B>2008</B></P>
</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=10.267>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="background-color:#ECECEC; border-top:0.5pt solid #000000; border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=8.333>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=414.733><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Weighted average expected rates of return on plan assets</P>
</TD><TD valign=bottom width=131.933><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>6.79%</P>
</TD><TD valign=bottom width=11.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD valign=bottom width=107.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>7.05%</P>
</TD><TD valign=bottom width=10.267>&nbsp;</TD><TD valign=bottom width=8.333>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=top width=414.733><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Weighted average discount rates used to determine the pension and post-retirement obligations</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=131.933><P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>6.44%</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=11.6>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=107.4><P style="margin:0pt; padding-right:2.55pt; font-family:Arial" align=right>6.11%</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=10.267>&nbsp;</TD><TD style="border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000" valign=bottom width=8.333>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Pension and post-retirement costs had a &#8364; 72 million net negative effect on &#8220;income (loss) before tax and discontinued operations&#8221; during the first six months of 2009 (&#8364;&nbsp;131 million increase in pre-tax income during the first six months of 2008). </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The weighted average expected rates of return on pension and post-retirement plan assets used to determine Alcatel-Lucent pension and post-retirement credits are established at the beginning of each fiscal year. The decrease in the weighted average expected rates of return on pension and post-retirement plan assets between 2008 and 2009 is mainly due to adjustments in expected future returns based on studies performed by Alcatel-Lucent external investment advisors. Even if the actual financial markets are very volatile, this assumption is required to be a long-term expected rate of return rather than a prediction of the immediate next period performance and is not reviewed every quarter. In addition, these rates that are used to determine the pension expense or income are applied on the opening fair value. For Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s U.S. plans, the pension expense or income is updated every quarter. Therefore, the 2009 second quarter expected return on pl
an assets (accounted for in financial income) for Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s U.S. plans is based on March 31, 2009 plan asset fair values, whereas the expected return on plan assets for non U.S. Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s plans is based on the fair values of plan assets at December 31, 2008. The interest cost associated with the plan liabilities is also impacted by the change in discount rates used to value the plan liabilities. The Group recognized a US$&nbsp;71 million decrease between the first and the second quarters of 2009 in the net pension credit, which is accounted for in &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148; (expected return on plan assets for Alcatel-Lucent&#146;s U.S. plans due to the decline of the plan asset fair values and expected change of the interest cost in relation with the decrease of the liability). On U.S. plans, the Group expects a US$ 65 million increase of the net pension credit to be accounted for in financial result between the 2009 second quarter and the 2009 third quarter.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Plans assets are invested in many different asset categories (such as cash, equities, bonds, real estate, private equity, etc&#133;). In the quarterly update of plan asset fair values, approximately 80% are based on closing date fair values and 20% have a one to three month delay as the fair value of private equity, venture capital, real estate and absolute return investments are not available in a short period. This is standard practice in the investment management industry. Assuming that the June 30, 2009 actual fair value of private equity, venture capital, real estate and absolute return on investments was 10% lower than the ones used for accounting purposes as of June 30, 2009, since the Management Pension Plan has a material investment in these assets classes (and the asset ceiling is not applicable to these plans), equity will be negatively impacted by approximately &#8364;&nbsp;210 million.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For the purposes of calculating any net pension and post-retirement credit, the discount rates are determined at the beginning of each quarterly period (for significant plans). For the purposes of determining the plan obligations, these rates are determined at the end of each period. Alcatel-Lucent is using a discount rate of 6.44% during fiscal 2009 to determine plan obligations. The change in the discount rate from 2008 was due to increasing long-term interest rates. Discount rates also are somewhat volatile because they are set based upon the prevailing rates as of the measurement date. The discount rate used to determine the post-retirement benefit costs is slightly lower due to a shorter expected duration of post-retirement plan obligations as compared to pension plan obligations. A lower discount rate increases the plan obligations and the Alcatel-Lucent net pension and post-retirement credit and profitability, whereas a higher discount rate reduce
s the plan obligations and the Alcatel-Lucent net pension and post-retirement credit and profitability.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The expected rate of return on pension and post-retirement plan assets and the discount rate were determined in accordance with consistent methodologies.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Holding all other assumptions constant, a 0.5% increase or decrease in the discount rate would have decreased or increased the 2008 net pension and post-retirement result by approximately &#8364;&nbsp;28&nbsp;million and &#8364;&nbsp;34&nbsp;million, respectively. A 0.5% increase or decrease in the expected return on plan assets would have increased or decreased the 2008 net pension and post-retirement result by approximately &#8364;&nbsp;133 million. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Group&#8217;s U.S. companies have taken various actions to reduce their share of retiree health care costs, including the shifting or increases of certain costs to their retirees. Health care benefits for employees who retired from Lucent&#146;s predecessor prior to March 1, 1990 are not subject to annual dollar caps on Lucent&#146;s share of future benefit costs. The benefit obligation associated with this retiree group approximated 59% of the total U.S. retiree health care obligation as of December 31, 2008. Management employees who retired on or after March 1, 1990 have paid amounts above the applicable annual dollar caps on Lucent's share of future benefit costs since 2001.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F23</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Beginning in 2009, the Group participated in a Medicare Private Fee For Service (PFFS) plan for Medicare eligible management retirees in the US. &nbsp;Initially, the Group&#146;s Medicare payments to the PFFS plan is somewhat higher than its Medicare payments to individuals. The Group expects the additional Medicare payments to the PFFS plan to decline by 90% over a 10-year period. However, the decrease for 2010 will be larger than anticipated. The Group expects to reflect this effect during the 2009 third quarter when it finalizes its negotiations with the PFFS plan provider.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Lucent&#146;s collective bargaining agreements were ratified during December&nbsp;2004 and address retiree health care benefits, among other items. Lucent agreed to continue to subsidize these benefits up to the established cap level consistent with current actuarial assumptions. Except for costs attributable to an implementation period that ended on February 1, 2005, costs that are in excess of this capped level are being borne by the retirees in the form of premiums and plan design changes. Lucent also agreed to establish a US$&nbsp;400 million trust that is being funded by Lucent over eight years and managed jointly by trustees appointed by Lucent and the unions. This trust is currently being funded by Section 420 transfers from the over funded Occupational Pension Plan. The trust is being used to mitigate the cost impact on retirees of premiums or plan design changes. The agreements also acknowledge that retiree health care benefits will no longer be
 a required subject of bargaining between Lucent and the unions.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amount of prepaid pension costs that can be recognized in our financial statements is limited to the sum of (i) the cumulative unrecognized net actuarial losses and past service cost, (ii) the present value of any available refunds from the plan, and (iii) any reduction in future contributions to the plan. As Lucent currently intends to use eligible excess pension assets applicable to formerly represented retirees to fund certain retiree healthcare benefits for such retirees, such use has been considered as a reimbursement from the pension plan. The funded status of the formerly represented retiree health care obligation of &#8364;&nbsp;1,607 million as of June 30, 2009 (&#8364;&nbsp;1,479 million as of December 31, 2008), the present value of Medicare Part D subsidies of approximately &#8364;&nbsp;262 million as of June 30, 2009 (as this amount is currently netted in the retiree health care obligation - &#8364;&nbsp;272 million as of December 31, 20
08) and the present value of future service costs of &#8364;&nbsp;46 million as of June 30, 2009 (&#8364;&nbsp;61 million as of December 31, 2008) have been considered in determining the asset ceiling limitation for Lucent's pension plans as of June 30, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The impact of expected future economic benefits on the pension plan asset ceiling is a complex matter. Based on latest estimates, as of the January 1, 2009 valuation date, there were approximately &#8364;&nbsp;1.8 billion of pension plan assets that would be eligible for &quot;collectively bargained&quot; transfers to fund retiree health care costs for Lucent&#8217;s formerly represented retirees (alternatively, &#8364;&nbsp;2.1 billion would be available for &#8220;multi-year&#8221; transfers, which also require the plan to remain 120% funded during the transfer period). This amount is sufficient to address the obligation arising from the healthcare being provided to Lucent&#146;s formerly represented retirees and as a result the Group should be able to utilize pension plan assets for Section 420 &#147;collectively bargained&#148; or &#147;multi-year&#148; transfers to fund all its health care obligations for Lucent&#146;s formerly represented retirees.
 Changes in plan asset values, funding levels or new legislation could result in significant changes in the asset ceiling that will impact our equity and could impact the ultimate amount of plan assets eligible for Section 420 transfers.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In December 2008, the Group made a Section 420 transfer of US$&nbsp;653 million to cover the health care costs for Lucent's formerly represented retirees for 2008 and nine months of 2009. This had an US$&nbsp;270&nbsp;million positive impact in the consolidated statement of cash flows in the fourth quarter of 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The impact of the different actuarial assumptions on the level of the funded status could have consequences on the funding requirements and the determination of the asset ceiling, which would affect our ability to make Section 420 transfers in the future and use the overfunding of some pension plans to fund underfunded healthcare plans related to the same beneficiaries.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>h/ Revenue recognition</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As indicated in note 1o, revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or to be received when the Group has transferred the significant risks and rewards of ownership of a product to the buyer.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For revenues and expenses generated from construction contracts, the Group applies the percentage of completion method of accounting, provided certain specified conditions are met, based either on the achievement of contractually defined milestones or on costs incurred compared with total estimated costs. The determination of the stage of completion and the revenues to be recognized rely on numerous estimations based on costs incurred and acquired experience. Adjustments of initial estimates can, however, occur throughout the life of the contract, which can have significant impacts on future net income (loss).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Although estimates inherent in construction contracts are subject to uncertainty, certain situations exist whereby management is unable to reliably estimate the outcome of a construction contract. These situations can occur during the early stages of a contract due to a lack of historical experience or throughout the contract as significant uncertainties develop related to additional costs, claims and performance obligations, particularly with new technologies. During the fourth quarter of 2007, as a result of cost overruns and major technical problems that we experienced in implementing a large W-CDMA contract, we determined that we could no longer estimate with sufficient reliability the final revenue and associated costs of such contract. As a result, we expensed all the contract costs incurred to that date, but we only recognized revenues to the extent that the contract costs incurred were recoverable. Consequently, revenues of &#8364;&nbsp;72 millio
n and cost of sales of &#8364;&nbsp;298 million were recognized in 2007 in connection with this construction contract. The negative impact on income (loss) before income tax and discontinued operations of changing from the percentage of completion method to this basis of accounting was &#8364;&nbsp;98 million for 2007. No change in the accounting treatment occurred in 2008 and during the first six months of 2009. If and when reliable estimates become available, revenue and costs associated with the construction contract will then be recognized respectively by reference to the stage of completion of the contract activity at the statement of financial position date. Future results of operations may therefore be impacted.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F24</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For arrangements to sell software licenses with services, software license revenue is recognized separately from the related service revenue, provided the transaction adheres to certain criteria (as prescribed by the Statement of Position SOP 97-2 of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, or the AICPA), such as the existence of sufficient vendor-specific objective evidence (&quot;VSOE&quot;) to determine the fair value of the various elements of the arrangement. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Some of the Group's products include software that is embedded in the hardware at delivery. In those cases, where indications are that software is more than incidental, such as where the transaction includes software upgrades or enhancements, more prescriptive software revenue recognition rules are applied to determine the amount and timing of revenue recognition. As products with embedded software are continually evolving, as well as the features and functionality of the product driven by software components that are becoming more critical to their operation and success in the market, the Group is continually assessing the applicability of some of the guidance of SOP 97-2 including whether software is more than incidental. Several factors are considered in making this determination including (i) whether the software is a significant focus of the marketing effort or is sold separately, (ii) whether updates, upgrades and other support services are provide
d on the software component and (iii) whether the cost to develop the software component of the product is significant in relation to the costs to develop the product as a whole. The determination of whether the evolution of our products and marketing efforts should result in the application of some of SOP 97-2 guidance requires the use of significant professional judgment. Further, the Group believes that reasonable people evaluating similar facts and circumstances may come to different conclusions regarding the most appropriate accounting model to apply in this environment. Our future results of operations may be significantly impacted, particularly due to the timing of revenue recognition, if we change our assessment as to whether software is incidental, particularly if VSOE or similar fair value cannot be obtained with respect to one or more of the undelivered elements.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For product sales made through distributors, product returns that are estimated according to contractual obligations and past sales statistics are recognized as a reduction of sales. Again, if the actual product returns were considerably different from those estimated, the resulting impact on the net income (loss) could be significant. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>It can be difficult to evaluate the Group&#146;s capacity to recover receivables. Such evaluation is based on the customers&#146; creditworthiness and on the Group&#146;s capacity to sell such receivables without recourse. If, subsequent to revenue recognition, the recoverability of a receivable that had been initially considered as likely becomes doubtful, a provision for an impairment loss is then recorded (see note 2b above).</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Alcatel-Lucent had a fire in a newly-built factory containing new machinery. Non recoverable assets having a net book value of <I>&#8364;</I>&nbsp;4&nbsp;million were written off as of September&nbsp;30, 2008 representing an equivalent negative impact on cost of sales in 2008. The cost of the physical damage and business interruption are insured and will give right to an indemnity claim, the amount of which is currently being assessed by our insurers. Indemnity payments will be accounted for as other revenue once virtually certain and reliable estimates are available, which could take up to one to two years to determine. Other revenue of &#8364;&nbsp;16 million was accounted for during the first six months 2009 related to the indemnification of damaged assets.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>i/ Purchase price allocation of a business combination</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In a business combination, the acquirer must allocate the cost of the business combination at the acquisition date by recognizing the acquiree&#146;s identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities at fair value at that date. The allocation is based upon certain valuations and other studies performed with the assistance of outside valuation specialists. Due to the underlying assumptions made in the valuation process, the determination of those fair values requires estimations of the effects of uncertain future events at the acquisition date and the carrying amounts of some assets, such as fixed assets, acquired through a business combination could therefore differ significantly in the future.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As prescribed by IFRS 3, if the initial accounting for a business combination can be determined only provisionally by the end of the reporting period in which the combination is effected, the acquirer must account for the business combination using those provisional values and has a twelve-month period to complete the purchase price allocation. Any adjustment of the carrying amount of an identifiable asset or liability made as a result of completing the initial accounting is accounted for as if its fair value at the acquisition date had been recognized from that date. Detailed adjustments accounted for in the allocation period are disclosed in note 3.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F25</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Once the initial accounting of a business combination is complete, only errors may be corrected.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:12.75pt; text-indent:-12.75pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>j/ Accounting treatment of convertible bonds with optional redemption periods/dates before contractual maturity</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Some of our convertible bonds have optional redemption periods/dates before their contractual maturity as described in note 15. All the convertible bonds issues by Alcatel-Lucent were accounted for in accordance with IAS 32 requirements (paragraphs 28 to 32) as described above in note 1-m. Classification of the liability and equity component of a convertible instrument is not revised as a result of a change in the likelihood that a conversion will be exercised. On the other hand, in case of optional redemption periods/dates occurring before the contractual maturity of the debenture, the likelihood of a redemption before the contractual maturity could lead to a change in the estimated payments. As prescribed by IAS 39, if an issuer revises the estimates of payment, due to reliable new estimates, it must adjust the carrying amount of the instrument by computing the present value of remaining cash flows at the original effective interest rate of the financi
al liability to reflect the revised estimated cash flows. The adjustment is recognized as income or expense in profit or loss.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As described in notes 6, 15 and 17, such a change in estimates occurred during the second quarter of 2009 regarding Lucent&#146;s 2.875% Series A convertible debenture. Similar changes in estimates could occur in the future for all convertible debentures with optional redemption periods/dates. The potential impact from a change in the Group&#146;s estimate of redemption triggers on all of Lucent&#146; convertible debt on &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148; will be a loss corresponding to the difference between the present value of the revised estimated cash flows and the carrying amount derived from the split accounting as described in note 1-m. An approximation of the potential negative impact in &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148; is the carrying amount of the equity component, as disclosed in notes 15 and 17.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>If all or some of the holders of Lucent&#146;s 2.875% Series A convertible debentures do not ask for redemption on the first optional redemption date (i.e. on June 15, 2010), the estimated cash flows related to the remaining debt will then be revised accordingly, if new estimates are considered as reliable, with corresponding potential positive impact on &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148;. The initial accounting treatment could then be reinstituted.</P>
<P style="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:3pt; line-height:14pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:12pt; border-bottom:2.25pt solid #000000" align=justify><B>Note 3 Changes in consolidated companies</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The main changes in consolidated companies for the first six months of 2009 were as follows. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">On April 30, 2009, we and Bharti Airtel announced the formation of a joint venture to manage Bharti Airtel&#8217;s pan-India broadband and telephone services and help Airtel&#8217;s transition to a next generation network across India. A new legal entity is being formed which will be fully consolidated by us before the end of 2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">The sale of our 20.8% stake in Thales was completed during the second quarter of 2009 with a capital gain of &#8364; 255 million accounted for in &#8220;other financial income (loss)&#8221;. This capital gain takes into account the &#8364; 191 million corresponding to the remaining part of the capital gain that was accounted for on different assets disposed of or contributed to Thales in the past, and which was eliminated as an intra-group transaction.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">The purchase price of &#8364;670 million paid to the Group by Thales for the disposal of the space business completed in 2007 was subject to adjustment in 2009. As a result, Thales is required to pay to the Group an additional &#8364;&nbsp;130 million (before fees), which is accounted for in &#8220;income from discontinued operations&#8221;.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The main changes in consolidated companies for 2008 were as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">On December 19, 2008, Alcatel-Lucent and Dassault Aviation announced that they had signed the definitive agreement to sell our shares in Thales (41,262,481 shares) at a price of &#8364;&nbsp;38 per share, representing a total value of &#8364;&nbsp;1.57 billion. The closing of the transaction, subject to regulatory and administrative approvals (mainly relative to antitrust), was foreseen for spring 2009. The carrying value of our shares was therefore reclassified as &#147;assets held for sale&#148; as of December 31, 2008. As the fair value less costs to sell was higher than the carrying value as of December 31, 2008, such carrying value was not adjusted. The amount of the capital gain that would be accounted for in &#147;other financial income (loss)&#148;, after the disposal of our shares had been completed, depended on the definitive amount of Thales&#146; equity as of December 31, 2008, which was not known when
 our 2008 consolidated financial statements were closed. The carrying value of our shares and the share in net income of equity affiliates related to Thales were based upon the available estimates that Thales management provided at the date of publication of the 2008 consolidated financials. The remaining part of the capital gain that was accounted for on our different assets disposed of or contributed to Thales in the past, and which was eliminated as an intra-group transaction, was accounted for also in&#8221;other financial income (loss)&#8221;, as part of the capital gain on the disposal of Thales shares, in the second quarter of 2009, representing a positive impact of &#8364;&nbsp;191 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F26</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<HR style="padding-top:7.2pt; padding-bottom:7.2pt" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="page-break-before:always; margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">On May 12, 2008, Alcatel-Lucent and Reliance Communications announced the formation of a global joint venture to offer managed network services to telecom operators. The first project of this joint venture is to provide managed services for Reliance Communications CDMA and GSM networks in India. Alcatel-Lucent controls the operations of the joint venture and fully consolidates it.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">On June 17, 2008, Alcatel-Lucent announced that it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Motive, Inc, a leading provider of service management software for broadband and mobile data services, through a cash tender offer for all outstanding Motive shares at a price of US $2.23 per share, representing a value of approximately US$67.8 million. Based upon the preliminary purchase price allocation, goodwill for this acquisition amounted to &#8364;&nbsp;58 million as of December 31, 2008. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:3pt; line-height:14pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:12pt; border-bottom:2.25pt solid #000000" align=justify><B>Note 4 Information by operating segment and by geographical segment</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with IFRS 8 &#8220;Operating Segments&#8221;, the information by operating segment comes from the business organization and activities of Alcatel-Lucent.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The tables below present information for the operating segments described hereunder. They take into account the new organization announced in the fourth quarter 2008 and comprise four operating segments: Applications Software, Carrier, Services and Enterprise. This new organization was effective January 1, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The information reported for each of our four operating segments is the same as that presented to the Chief Operating Decision Maker (i.e. the Chief Executive Officer) and is used to make decisions on resource allocation and to assess performance. As of January 1, 2009, the four operating segments are:</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Carrier: streamlined to encompass only four business divisions, IP, Optics, Wireless and Wireline.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Applications Software: a new operating segment that consolidates the various software businesses that were previously spread throughout the Group, and is designed to increase our focus on and support for our software applications business. The Applications Software segment is an integral part of our new strategic focus on new services and applications that combine the trusted capabilities of the network with the creative services delivered over the internet. This segment consists of the Applications Software business division that had previously been part of the former Carrier business group, the Genesys contact center software business that had previously been part of the Enterprise business group, and the Operations Support Systems and Business Support Systems (OSS/BSS) software businesses that had previously been part of the Services business group.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Enterprise: focused on small, medium and large enterprises and is unchanged compared to the former Enterprise business group apart from the exclusion of Genesys now reported under the Applications Software segment.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:21.3pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:21.3pt; font-family:Symbol" align=justify><FONT FACE="Arial">Services: focused on managed services, professional services, and network integration. It no longer includes OSS/BSS (operations support systems/business support systems) software activities that are now part of the Applications Software segment.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The information presented below is restated to take into account the new organization described above. Additionally, the presentation of certain other information, such as the difference between the employee bonus accrual and the initially budgeted amount is modified to be presented within each operating segment, whereas it used to be presented in the &#147;Other &amp; and unallocated amounts&#148; column in the former segment information. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The information by operating segment follows the same accounting policies as those used and described in these condensed interim consolidated financial statements. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All inter-segment commercial relations are conducted on an arm&#146;s length basis on terms and conditions identical to those prevailing for the supply of goods and services to third parties. </P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=center>F27</P>
<P style="margin:0pt; font-family:Arial" align=justify><BR></P>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=82.267><P style="margin:0pt; line-height:11pt; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" align=right>460</P>
